The investing world has its own version of tea leaves: interest rates. You may as well read one as take a guess on the other. Here are some ETF ideas to consider as you sort through the hawkish and dovish signals from the Fed on policy normalization.  Go shorter. With a rate hike looking ever more likely, investors should…

The first quarter was a stock pickers' market, given the great divide between the leaders and the laggards. Coffee heated up 62% as copper was hammered 11%. Russia crashed 17% while Egypt rallied 24%.
How should investors position their portfolios in the second quarter? We asked several professional investing strategists for their outlook on the stock market and single best ETF recommendation.

1. Martin Kremenstein, head of U.S. ETFs at Deutsche Asset & Wealth Management with $63 billion in assets under management in New York City: I think we've seen a strong indication that the Federal Reserve under Janet Yellen will continue to taper its quantitative easing policy, which will naturally lead to a strong U.S. dollar vs. both developed and emerging market currencies.

In this market environment, investors should consider hedging their non-U.S. equity investments against a strengthening U.S. dollar. Db X-trackers MSCI EAFE Hedged Equity (DBEF) is designed to provide exposure to securities in developed international stock markets while at the same time mitigating exposure to fluctuations between the value of the U.S. dollar and non-U.S. currencies from 22 component countries.

As developed markets outside of the U.S. continue to look increasingly interesting from both a valuation and recovery standpoint, the currency-hedge strategy offered by the ETF is a great investment idea for 2014. The structure of DBEF allows an investor to remain invested abroad, while still being protected against the impending rise of the U.S. dollar.

2. Prateek Mehrotra, chief investment officer at Endowment Wealth Management with $50 million in AUM in Appleton, Wis.: Our outlook for the U.S. and global stock markets is positive for the current calendar year, albeit with a little more volatility than last year. Valuations in the U.S. are reasonable and not stretched by any parameter. Global markets are cheaper vs. the U.S. on a pure valuation basis. Equities are still cheaper relative to fixed income.

As long as corporate America continues to churn out good earnings growth, stocks will have a tail wind, given that we still have a loose monetary-policy environment, low inflation and the global economy is continuing to grow, barring any unforeseen geopolitical event that could turn the tables.

One area that we like as contrarians is emerging markets in general and the BRIC countries (Brazil, Russia, India and China) in particular. We generally do not recommend sector- or country-specific ETFs. However, we have strong contrarian conviction in Market Vectors India Small Caps (SCIF) and Guggenheim BRIC (EEB).

SCIF has fallen over 19% annualized over the last three years, whereas EEB has fallen over 9% annualized. Assuming a reversion to the mean occurs, we believe that going forward, the returns could be higher than the rest of the markets. India's elections in May could spur a political party change at the top, which should bode well for the exchange rate and small caps. A new central banker at the helm of monetary affairs has already put a leash on runaway inflation.
Obviously, the risks to this thesis lie in the unintended consequences from the Fed's tapering causing the continuation of money flows away from high current account deficit countries like India.

3. Dick Wolfe, managing director at Saddle River Capital Management with $27 million AUM in Saddle River, N.J.: The market was expected to be up around 10% this year, but it looks like it's going to be up around 7% for 2014. That means the market is slow to get moving. For the next quarter, gross domestic product (growth) should pick up, as it didn't do that well in first quarter.

We anticipate the market to be more positive in the second quarter. It is likely the weather had a lot to do with the slow market. Also risk is up a bit with the Ukraine situation and the unknown outcome of what Russia will eventually do or not do there.

Going forward, we are bullish on health care ETFs, particularly the Health Care Select Sector SPDR (XLV). Companies like Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), one of the top holdings of XLV, are undervalued. With the passing of ObamaCare, there are lots more people signing on to insurance, thus making health care companies a large beneficiary of this legislation.

The risks are a bit lower in the health care space because they are value-style companies. XLV has outperformed so far this year and will continue to do so. It has a nice dividend yield and low-volatility companies.

4. Tim Landolt, managing director at ETF Model Solutions in Appleton, Wis.: Our firm has a positive bias towards equities for 2014 although we expect equities may see corrective activity in 2014 after the strong gains of 2013. Equities appear a bit tired right now, and we perhaps are experiencing some of that correction activity now. A correction is healthy for longer-term investors.
While gold has received more media attention, some of the broader agricultural commodity indexes have very quietly experienced returns of 10% or more and have been holding those gains very nicely.

Elements Rogers International Commodity Agricultural ETN (RJA) looks attractive right now. After an approximate 10% gain in the first quarter, there has been a pause the past few weeks that has been constructive and offers the possibility that could continue to advance into the second quarter.

A confluence of factors could prolong the move, including the ongoing drought in California, livestock numbers that are near 65-year lows, growing worldwide demand from improving global economies, the drought in Brazil and the unrest in grain-producing Ukraine.

Of course, commodities are typically more volatile than other asset classes, and prices are driven by supply-and-demand issues that are not highly predictable. For instance, drought-ending rains or a good spring planting season in the U.S. could bring a correction as investors anticipate a bumper grain crop in the fall. There is also the underlying credit risk with any ETN that investors should consider on a case-by-case basis.

5. J. Andre Weisbrod, CEO and chief investing officer at Starr Financial Advisors with $41 million AUM in Pittsburgh, Pa.: I think this market is struggling to retain its momentum. From a historical and common-sense perspective, it (is) reasonable to expect more than a 5% correction to keep this market honest. Without a good pullback, we risk at least a modest bubble. I think this market is due for a 10% pullback, and if that doesn't happen, a sideways trading range is the second most likely scenario.

Some sectors' and companies' prices are approaching higher valuation ranges that increase risk. We are also concerned about continued systemic risks in the financial and government sectors. We should not underestimate the risks of extreme debt ratios, fractured leadership and geopolitical risks.

Given such conditions, we like iShares S&P Global Infrastructure Index (IGF). It offers global diversification with only about one-third of U.S. stocks, significant positions in utilities (40%), industrials (39%) and energy (19%). IGF holdings appear to be reasonably valued to slightly undervalued. Plus it is currently paying a 3.3% dividend. The global exposure is also self-hedging against any major currency fluctuations.

This ETF is likely to hold up better than the major indexes during 10% or greater market correction. It has been going up over the past couple weeks, while the broader indexes have faltered. And the long-term total return potential, while not extraordinary, is very healthy. This is a way to keep hitting singles and scoring well rather than relying on a grand slam to win the game.

6. Vern Sumnicht, founder and CEO of iSectors with $150 million AUM in Appleton, Wis.: Despite the poor results of the U.S. stock market and recent volatility, I still see the U.S. stock market doing well in 2014.

The activist nature of the Federal Reserve will prevent volatility from escalating into a more serious market downturn. I've been recommending investors overweight large-cap value with a focus on those companies that have been consistently increasing dividends over the last 10 or more years. With the Fed's accommodative protection, the nice dividend yield and liquidity these dividend-yielding stocks provide are one of the few attractive places left to put all that newly printed money from central banks around the world.

While that money has been inflating equities and keeping interest rates artificially low, at some point the newly printed money from the Fed must slow down and stop. At that point interest rates and inflation will move higher and bonds will go lower. The fear of Federal Reserve policies causes me to direct investors' fixed-income purchases toward very short-term bonds to achieve better returns than cash and avoid losing principal when interest rates do increase.

Over the last few weeks, events in Ukraine have opened the eyes of the world to Russian president Vladimir Putin's agenda. Putin's move on Ukraine's Crimea, without a significant U.S. response to protect them, increases free-world fear and economic uncertainty, and adds to volatility.

Investors will continue to turn to gold as an uncorrelated investment to dampen volatility. Investors also want an investment with upside potential during periods of market volatility and economic uncertainty. Market Vectors Junior Gold Miners (GDXJ) is a satellite investment that still remains significantly undervalued and fits an increasingly volatile and uncertain market environment.

Three years ago GDXJ was $170 a share. Today, despite moving up a bit in the first quarter it is $37 a share. This ETF holds 68 attractive gold-mining stocks; 95% are in Canada, Australia and the U.S. Investors need to remember 400% to 500% potential upside comes with risk. However, selling at book value today with increasing political uncertainty and looming inflation, I'd think there is relatively limited downside.The first quarter was a stock pickers' market, given the great divide between the leaders and the laggards. Investors also want an investment with upside potential during periods of market volatility and economic uncertainty. Market Vectors Junior Gold Miners (GDXJ) is a satellite investment that still remains significantly undervalued and fits an increasingly volatile and uncertain market environment.Three years ago GDXJ was $170 a share. Today, despite moving up a bit in the first quarter it is $37 a share. This ETF holds 68 attractive gold-mining stocks; 95% are in Canada, Australia and the U.S. Investors need to remember 400% to 500% potential upside comes with risk. However, selling at book value today with increasing political uncertainty and looming inflation, I'd think there is relatively limited downside.

The old stock market adage "sell in May and go away" may have to be replaced with "winners and losers switch places in May." India ETFs have turned red hot, while coffee went cold in May. But investing strategists expect the tables to turn again. EGShares India Small Cap (SCIN) has outperformed all nonleveraged ETFs, rallying 26% for the month…
Yale professor Robert Shiller, honored with a Nobel prize in economics Monday along with Eugene Fama and Lars Hansen, has also made a splash in the ETF industry, including a couple of belly flops.
The now defunct financial services firm MacroMarkets LLC and Shiller teamed up to launch MacroShares Major Metro Housing Up (UMM) and MacroShares Major Metro Housing Down (DMM) in May 2009.

The two structurally complicated funds, which weren't actually ETFs, were designed to offer triple-leveraged long and short exposure to the U.S. housing market based on the S&P/Case-Shiller Composite-10 Home Price Index, developed by Shiller and Karl Case.

Shiller said the funds provided a liquid and transparent indicator of where "investors believe U.S. home prices are headed." Despite Shiller's fame for calling the housing bubble and the index being the most closely watched measure of home values, UMM and DMM were shuttered after just seven months of trading in December 2009.

The funds were flawed in their design and couldn't track the underlying index, says Ron Rowland, founder of InvestWithAnEdge.comAmong many issues, they fluctuated in price every day, while the index was updated once a month. They could only be issued and redeemed in pairs and so they couldn't accommodate investor bias to one side.
Shiller struck most lasting success with Barclays ETN+ Shiller CAPE ETN (CAPE), which debuted on the stock market a year ago. It's gathered just $13 million in assets.

It tracks the Cyclically Adjusted Price Earnings Ratio, or CAPE Ratio, created by Shiller and John Y. Several foreign banks have broken out of bases lately in an unusually broad display of strength.IBD's foreign banks industry group has shot up to the top 20 out of 197 groups, from 100 just three weeks ago. Banks in Argentina, India and Canada have crafted the most interesting charts.BBVA Banco Frances (BFR) broke out April 8. After triggering the 8% sell rule, the stock recovered and remains near the 9.47 buy point. The Argentine bank's earnings have snapped out of a dull period, surging 139% and 157% the past two quarters.Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL), another Argentina-based bank, broke out April 2 but has dipped just below the 13.15 entry. Galicia's earnings jumped 70% in the first quarter. It was a sharp improvement from the previous four quarters, when EPS rose 25% in Q3 and fell moderately the other three periods.The government is backtracking on populist economic policies, cutting subsidies and devaluing the currency.India-based HDFC Bank (HDB) and Icici Bank (IBN) broke out Friday from cup-with-handle bases. Both banks' financials are soft.Rather than growth prospects, these stocks are rallying on expectations that Narendra Modi, a pro-business candidate for prime minister, will win decisively.The two banks' shares mirror the Barclays iPath India (INP) ETN.Three Canadian stocks in IBD's money center banking industry group have broken out as well.CIBC (CM) and Toronto Dominion Bank (TD) remain near their buy points and new highs despite weak volume on their moves and declining profits.BMO Financial Group (BMO) is trying to clear a 69.69 buy point. The company also suffers from weak profit and revenue performance. It posts quarterly results May 28.In Peru, Credicorp (BAP) is trading near 52-week highs. The company is turning around its financial performance quickly, going from a streak of four quarters of EPS declines to a 30% increase in Q1.South Korea's thinly traded Shinhan Financial Group (SHG) broke out Tuesday, but its financials are spotty. Brazil's Banco Bradesco (BBD) cleared a 15.77 entry but has yet to find volume.Generally, economic improvement in Europe and other regions is helping banks."Steady growth in non-U.S. banks is stemming from the proactive steps taken by the central banks of most developed and emerging economies," Zacks noted in a February analysis. "But the global financial system is yet to show tidiness to ensure a steady backdrop for banks."
India's stock market soared to new highs Monday as investors banked on Narendra Modi of the pro-business Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to win the parliamentary elections.
Exit polls showed a Modi victory as voting ended Monday. But the final tally won't be released until Friday, and India's exit polls have been inaccurate in previous elections.

WisdomTree India Earnings Fund (EPI), with $1 billion in assets, gapped up 4% to 20.51, its highest since January 2013. EGShares India Infrastructure ETF (INXX) vaulted 5% to 12.34. Market Vectors Indian Rupee/USD ETN (INR), which measures India's currency against the U.S. dollar, jumped 3% to 36.00.

India's stock market has run too far too fast, and investor optimism over the election has already been priced in, says Michelle Gibley, director of international research with Schwab Center for Financial Research, based in Denver.

Modi, a Hindu nationalist, has pledged to create manufacturing jobs and overhaul the country's infrastructure. But to achieve the latter goal, Modi would need cooperation from local governments, which have been reluctant to enact reforms, says Gibley.
"They need to upgrade infrastructure to increase their growth potential and reduce their tendency to have high inflation," Gibley added.

India's consumer inflation rate was at 8.6% as of March, slightly lower than its 10% pace last year. The Reserve Bank of India has raised interest rates three times since September to dampen inflation. But raising rates has an equally negative effect of hindering economic growth, because it discourages borrowing and spending.

After lagging global markets last year, EPI has rebounded, rallying 17% year to date. It's outpaced iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) by 16% and iShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), which tracks developed foreign markets, by 15%. Last year, EPI sank 9.2%, EEM dipped 3.7% and EFA jumped 21.4%.

EPI and its emerging-market peers trade at cheap valuations compared with developed markets. It has a price-to-forward-earnings ratio of 11.4 and price-to-book-value of 1.6, according to Morningstar. EFA trades at nearly 15 times forward earnings and 1.5 times book value. SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY) trades at nearly 17 times earnings and 2.3 times book value.

"Deregulation of key protected sectors, like retail, and the advancement of free-market policies beyond what (Indian Prime Minister Manmohan) Singh initiated during his tenure would give investors a solid reason to diversify their exposures even further in Indian stocks," John Krey, an international investment analyst at S&P Investment Advisory Services, wrote in a report. "Pending the May polling results, risk-eager investors — who have not already re-entered the market — might be advised to consider doing so in the event BJP wins the election by a landslide."
Growing Population

Ethan Anderson, senior portfolio manager for Rehmann Financial with $1.5 billion in client assets in Grand Rapids, Mich., is bullish on India because of its rapidly growing, young consumer population.

"At a rate of 2.59 children per woman, the world's largest democracy is by far the only country from a gross domestic product standpoint that actually has a growing population when not accounting for immigration," Anderson said in an email.India's stock market soared to new highs Monday as investors banked on Narendra Modi of the pro-business Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to win the parliamentary elections.Exit polls showed a Modi victory as voting ended Monday. China's plan to build its first big passenger plane promises to reshape its fast-growing aviation market. A lot is at stake for U.S. companies.

Boeing (BA) delivered its 800th airplane to China earlier this year. It has an order backlog of nearly $30 billion from China. So the state-owned C919 jet program poses a potential threat. Boeing also is a big customer of parts makers trying to win C919-related business.

Several U.S. companies have signed contracts to supply parts for the C919, including General Electric (GE), Eaton (ETN), Rockwell Collins (COL), Honeywell (HON), Goodrich (GR) and Parker Hannifin (PH). "Western (aircraft) component and system suppliers see the writing on the wall, that the Boeing/Airbus duopoly is going away," said Tom Boozer, an analyst at Kirkland, Wash.-based consultancy G2 Solutions. "They recognize that the Chinese market could be a huge portion of their business."

China's aviation market is booming. Airline stocks, such as Hong Kong-listed Air China, China Southern (ZNH) and China Eastern (CEA), have rebounded strongly in 2010. Passenger traffic is growing 20% a year in China as domestic travel and trips abroad grow.
The country will open 10 airports in 2010, says the Civil Aviation Administration of China. The CAAC expects 250 airports by 2020, up from 176 at year-end.
Boeing projects that over the next two decades China will be the No. 2 aircraft buyer, behind the U.S. and ahead of the United Arab Emirates.

With the C919, China aims to satisfy some of its domestic demand and boost exports, initially in Asia. State-owned Commercial Aircraft Corp. of China (Comac) expects to sell 2,509 C919s over 20 years. The C919 is slated to fly in 2014 and enter service in 2016.

China aims to take a big step forward with the C919, a single-aisle passenger jet that will seat up to 190 people. Analysts say it should be a big improvement over a regional jet, the ARJ21, that Chinese companies cobbled together over the past 10 years.

But how will the C919 compare to Boeing's next-generation 737 and the Airbus A320 family? (Canada's Bombardier also is expanding into this market.) And how much leading-edge technology will U.S. companies provide for the C919 as they compete for business with each other and European rivals?
Comac has a strong bargaining position because of China's booming aviation market, analysts say.

But U.S. aircraft parts makers will be cautious transferring technology to China unless it provides intellectual property guarantees and does not favor local joint ventures, says Richard Aboulafia, VP at consultancy Teal Group.
He's not sure the C919 will get the latest and best technology.
"It's not clear what they'll be getting," Aboulafia said. "Some may be state of the art. We don't know."

He added: "If you're a supplier, you're going to be wary of working with government-run factories if they're not giving you intellectual property protection. At the end of the day, it's China's government (in control) and they want to build national champions (in manufacturing). I think most companies will show up with stuff a few years behind the times."
Parts Makers Want A Piece

Comac seems to be getting a world-class, fuel-efficient engine for the C919 from CFM International, jointly owned by GE and France's Safran, analysts say. In late 2009, GE formed a joint venture with Aviation Industry Corp. of China to build C919 housing and gear. In July, GE and AVIC won a deal to provide an electronics system.

Honeywell has won C919 contracts to supply cockpit gear, braking systems and auxiliary power units. Eaton in July formed a venture with Shanghai Aircraft Manufacturing Co., a Comac subsidiary, to develop fuel and hydraulic systems.
Comac is expected to unveil more C919 contracts in the fall.
The U.S. Chamber of Commerce says China's policies are worrisome.

"The Chinese government's core strategy for assembling the C919 is to trade market access for technology," the Chamber said in July. "No doubt the involved foreign suppliers are hoping for long-term China market access through these partnerships and technology transfers. The concern is that when Comac is able to take care of itself indigenously, the foreign aerospace firm may find themselves sidelined and competing globally against the Chinese companies they are now creating."
U.S. companies have no choice but to try to get in on the ground floor as China builds an aerospace industry, says Boozer.
"They're going to disclose IP and provide product because that's where the growth is," he said. "If they don't, someone else will.

"So they're putting their best foot forward, bringing engineering expertise over (for the C919). But aircraft are incredibly complex. The Chinese are going to make mistakes and they'll have to go back and fix them."
Aircraft and aircraft parts are two U.S. export strengths, helping the economies of Wichita, Kan.; Durham, N.C.; Cincinnati and Seattle, says a Brookings Institution study released in July.
No Sino-Jumbo, For Now

Air China, China Eastern and China Southern are expected to order the C919. Even if the C919 is successful, analysts say it'll take China a decade or more to develop bigger, twin-aisle passenger jets. Roughly half of Boeing's order backlog is for the 787 Dreamliner, which has yet to enter service.

Corporate jet maker Gulfstream, owned by General Dynamics (GD), aims to expand sales in China. While the C919 project has been well publicized, it's not clear where China stands in developing corporate aircraft, analysts say.

Chinese airlines, meanwhile, seem to have a lot going for them. They've been able to tap debt markets to fund fleet expansion, and a stronger yuan should help them lower fuel costs and capital outlays, analysts say.
China's airline sector has the second highest estimated earnings growth over the next year, just behind the metals and mining industry, according to Thomson/Reuters.

However, China is making a huge investment in high-speed rail. Rail competition could lower airline fares and slow the growth of airline traffic, wrote Singapore-based brokerage UOB Kay Hian Group and Hong Kong-based Citic Securities in separate reports.

"It depends partly on how much government involvement there is in setting prices," said John Strickland, director of U.K.-based JLS Consulting. He added that China is a big country, and airplanes will still be preferred for long-distance travel and cargo delivery.China's plan to build its first big passenger plane promises to reshape its fast-growing aviation market. A lot is at stake for U.S. companies.Boeing (BA) delivered its 800th airplane to China earlier this year. It has an order backlog of nearly $30 billion from China. Special Report: ETF Strategies

Exchange traded funds have a lot to offer: low costs, a focus on countless investment niches, pricing throughout the day. But some types entail risk that unwary investors might fall prey to — such as unfamiliar terms and exotic strategies.
Pay attention to these potential pitfalls to avoid financial injury while you invest:
 Contango. People might think contango is a form of dirty dancing. Instead, it's a dirty word — at least on Wall Street, and especially for some ETFs.

The term refers to what happens to an account when futures contracts are rolled from expiring ones to new ones when commodity prices are rising. Proceeds from the old contract buy less of the new, more expensive contract.
The investor ends up selling low and buying high, over and over. That's different from buying the underlying commodity and profiting as it gains value.
Some ETFs use a rolling series of contracts, locking themselves into a series of successively higher priced contracts. Each new buy destroys shareholder value.
Solution: Check a commodity ETF's strategy before buying. Beware of funds that automatically roll into front-month contracts.
Another option: Use a contango killer such as iShares Dow Jones-UBS Roll Select Commodity Index Trust (CMDT), which shops for contracts with the least contango.
Third option: Look for an inverse commodity ETF that profits as forward contracts lose value — basically a form of shorting.
 Backwardation. This is a flip side of contango. Each future contract for a commodity is lower in price than the preceding one.
This happens when supplies are tight, making buyers willing to pay more at today's spot price.
Beware: If supplies loosen, the gravy train can derail.
 ETNs vs. ETFs. An exchange traded note, a cousin of the ETF, is a debt instrument. As senior, unsecured and unsubordinated, it has the credit risk of its issuer.
Unlike an ETF, an ETN does not hold any stocks, bonds or commodities. An ETN promises to pay investors the amount equal to its index, minus fees. And an ETN has a maturity date, with many callable.

Also, ETNs are often more expensive than ETFs. One key benefit: Since ETNs do not hold anything, they do not have any tracking error. The lack of trades makes ETNs more tax efficient. And an ETN can never be structured as a partnership, eliminating the tax hassle of filing a Form K-1.
 Bid-ask spread. That spread is the difference between the amount a buyer offers — the bid — and the price a seller demands — the ask.
The more thinly traded an ETF is, the wider its spread.
The spread represents your potential loss if you immediately sell an ETF after buying it. You may end up paying the higher price and receiving the lower one.
The 150 most active ETFs trade 450,000 shares or more a day. Of those, 135 have spreads below 5 cents, and 70 have spreads of 1 cent, according to S&P Capital IQ.
The 300 least active ETFs trade fewer than 5,000 shares a day. Of those, 257 have spreads greater than 10 cents, and 186 have spreads wider than 25 cents.
One safeguard: Check an ETF's trading volume. You can find that information at Investors.com, discount brokerage sites, Yahoo Finance and Morningstar.com.
To cope with potentially wide spreads, use a limit order instead of a market order.

 Master limited partnerships. A key appeal of MLP ETFs is that many — especially those that invest in oil and gas assets — pay high yields. Also, investing in MLPs via ETFs gives you more diversification than investing in individual MLPs. That cuts volatility.
Another benefit is that about 75% of MLP ETF distributions are returns of capital, which reduce your cost basis. The rest is treated mainly as a qualified dividend.
Most taxpayers pay 0% or 15% tax on them, rather than ordinary income rates. Even in the top bracket, taxpayers pay just 20%.
Tax reporting for MLP ETFs is far less complex than it is for individual MLPs.
A key drawback for MLP ETFs is that capital gains on underlying MLPs in an ETF are taxed heavily.

That cuts an MLP ETF's total return by about 30% vs. the same individual MLPs and by 10% if they're held in an ETN, says Will Braman, chief investment officer of Ballentine Partners, a Waltham, Mass., wealth management firm.
Most retail investors buy for the current pretax yield of 6%, Braman says, and they don't understand the tax impact. In today's environment, they're willing to break even on price.
He advises clients to hold MLPs through limited partnerships or separately managed accounts.
 Premium or discount to NAV. ETFs are designed to have little or no discount or premium to net asset value. Still, it has happened.
Having unexpected premiums or discounts can largely be avoided.
The net asset value, or NAV, of an ETF is the total value of securities in the portfolio divided by the number of shares outstanding.

Supply and demand can make the market price per share of an ETF deviate from its NAV per share. That difference is called a premium when the market price is higher. It's a discount when the market price is lower.
You can find the premium and discount at the fund's Web page, at many online brokerages and at Morningstar.com.

For example, Market Vectors China (PEK) closed at 33.33 on Oct. 7, a 2.49% premium to its 32.50 NAV. The Federal Reserve's Sept. 18 decision to not begin tapering its bond buys left intact investors' appetite for equity risk, especially in markets like China, Todd says.

Premiums and discounts tend to be smaller and less persistent for ETFs that track more liquid securities like U.S. stocks and government bonds. They're commonly larger and longer lasting for other categories, says Michael Iachini, managing director of ETF research at Charles Schwab Investment Advisory.
A drop in a premium while you hold an ETF is akin to the fund losing an equal amount of value. Check an ETF's premium-discount track record before buying to weigh what you're getting into.

Use a limit order to limit their potential impact when you're buying.Special Report: ETF StrategiesExchange traded funds have a lot to offer: low costs, a focus on countless investment niches, pricing throughout the day. As senior, unsecured and unsubordinated, it has the credit risk of its issuer.Unlike an ETF, an ETN does not hold any stocks, bonds or commodities. An ETN promises to pay investors the amount equal to its index, minus fees. And an ETN has a maturity date, with many callable.Also, ETNs are often more expensive than ETFs. One key benefit: Since ETNs do not hold anything, they do not have any tracking error. The lack of trades makes ETNs more tax efficient. And an ETN can never be structured as a partnership, eliminating the tax hassle of filing a Form K-1. Bid-ask spread. That spread is the difference between the amount a buyer offers — the bid — and the price a seller demands — the ask.The more thinly traded an ETF is, the wider its spread.The spread represents your potential loss if you immediately sell an ETF after buying it. You may end up paying the higher price and receiving the lower one.The 150 most active ETFs trade 450,000 shares or more a day. Of those, 135 have spreads below 5 cents, and 70 have spreads of 1 cent, according to S&P Capital IQ.The 300 least active ETFs trade fewer than 5,000 shares a day. Of those, 257 have spreads greater than 10 cents, and 186 have spreads wider than 25 cents.One safeguard: Check an ETF's trading volume. You can find that information at Investors.com, discount brokerage sites, Yahoo Finance and Morningstar.com.To cope with potentially wide spreads, use a limit order instead of a market order. Master limited partnerships. A key appeal of MLP ETFs is that many — especially those that invest in oil and gas assets — pay high yields. Also, investing in MLPs via ETFs gives you more diversification than investing in individual MLPs. That cuts volatility.Another benefit is that about 75% of MLP ETF distributions are returns of capital, which reduce your cost basis. The rest is treated mainly as a qualified dividend.Most taxpayers pay 0% or 15% tax on them, rather than ordinary income rates. Even in the top bracket, taxpayers pay just 20%.Tax reporting for MLP ETFs is far less complex than it is for individual MLPs.A key drawback for MLP ETFs is that capital gains on underlying MLPs in an ETF are taxed heavily.That cuts an MLP ETF's total return by about 30% vs. the same individual MLPs and by 10% if they're held in an ETN, says Will Braman, chief investment officer of Ballentine Partners, a Waltham, Mass., wealth management firm.Most retail investors buy for the current pretax yield of 6%, Braman says, and they don't understand the tax impact. In today's environment, they're willing to break even on price.He advises clients to hold MLPs through limited partnerships or separately managed accounts. Premium or discount to NAV. ETFs are designed to have little or no discount or premium to net asset value. Still, it has happened.Having unexpected premiums or discounts can largely be avoided.The net asset value, or NAV, of an ETF is the total value of securities in the portfolio divided by the number of shares outstanding.Supply and demand can make the market price per share of an ETF deviate from its NAV per share. That difference is called a premium when the market price is higher. It's a discount when the market price is lower.You can find the premium and discount at the fund's Web page, at many online brokerages and at Morningstar.com.For example, Market Vectors China (PEK) closed at 33.33 on Oct. 7, a 2.49% premium to its 32.50 NAV. The Federal Reserve's Sept. 18 decision to not begin tapering its bond buys left intact investors' appetite for equity risk, especially in markets like China, Todd says.Premiums and discounts tend to be smaller and less persistent for ETFs that track more liquid securities like U.S. stocks and government bonds. They're commonly larger and longer lasting for other categories, says Michael Iachini, managing director of ETF research at Charles Schwab Investment Advisory.A drop in a premium while you hold an ETF is akin to the fund losing an equal amount of value. Check an ETF's premium-discount track record before buying to weigh what you're getting into.Use a limit order to limit their potential impact when you're buying.
Stock futures were steadily mixed early Wednesday as Alcoa led the march into the third-quarter reporting season.
Dow futures were down 23 points. S&P 500 futures were off a fraction, while Nasdaq 100 futures kept just above the breakeven line.

The market's uptrend came under pressure Tuesday as the Nasdaq dropped through its 50-day line of support in heavy trade. The S&P 500 held above support, but is weighed down with six distribution days.

Alcoa (AA) set the reporting season wheels in motion late Tuesday with an unexpected rise in earnings and sales falling less than forecast by analysts. The aluminum maker pared its demand growth forecast for the full year. Shares were down a fraction early Wednesday.

Costco (COST) climbed 2% ahead of the bell. The discount club chain reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings well above analyst estimates, boosted by increased membership fees. The company had pre-reported better-than-expected revenue and same-store sales figures Oct. 4.

Danaher (DHR) and Cooper Industries (CBE) agreed to sell their Apex Tools joint venture to Bain Capital for $1.6 billion. Apex makes several brands of hand tools, including the Craftsman brand for Sears. Cooper is being acquired by Eaton (ETN) for $11.8 billion. Danaher shares rose slightly. Cooper was unchanged.

IBD 50 stocks trended toward mild gains in premarket trade. The widest move came from Elli Mae (ELLI), which rose 2%. The mortgage service origination firm dropped through 10-week support this week. It has been consolidating just below its Sept. 14 high, after sprinting 300% higher from a February breakout.

Overseas, Europe's major indexes carried thin losses at midday. China's markets finished narrowly mixed. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slammed down 2%, notching its worst two-day loss since July, after car markets reported lagging sales in China.

In commodities, crude oil held its place above $92 a barrel after a 3% surge Tuesday. Gold warmed slightly, trading above $1,768 an ounce, following its three-day decline. Agricultural commodities were generally lower ahead of a pair of key U.S. Department of Agriculture reports due out Thursday.

No major economic releases are due out Wednesday morning. But investors will look to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report of regional economic activity, due out at 2 p.m. EDT.Stock futures were steadily mixed early Wednesday as Alcoa led the march into the third-quarter reporting season.Dow futures were down 23 points. Special Report: ETF Strategies
Looking for a top-performing ETF? High volume and low costs are often traits of funds that had superior returns.
But there's usually more to the story.
All of the nearby tables are drawn from nonleveraged ETFs that have an average daily volume of at least 500,000 shares, as of Oct. 9.

Among those, the upper table shows the funds with the highest year-to-date return. The six with the highest returns this year all posted gains in excess of 30%. VelocityShares Daily Inverse Short-Term ETN (XIV) came in as the leader with a 55.79% gain.

XIV is linked to the inverse of the daily performance of the S&P 500 Short-Term Futures Index ER, minus its investor fee that amounts to 1.35% of assets a year. XIV reflects bets on the volatility of the S&P 500 index, based on futures contracts on the VIX, a popular measure of the benchmark's implied volatility.
XIV's average daily volume is 11.2 million shares. Not shabby — but well below the funds with the highest average daily volume, which are shown in the middle panel.
Those are led by the ETF universe's poster boy of popularity, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY). That ETF, which tracks the well-known broad market benchmark, sees an average of 109.5 million shares traded daily.
Its year-to-date return is 20.54%.

The absence of a reliable link between volume and performance is shown by the market return of iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF (EEM), which is the ETF with the second-highest average daily volume, 64.9 million shares.
Its year-to-date return is a weak 2.62% loss. The next two highest average daily volume ETFs also posted losses for the year.

Advisers often tout the importance of low cost. But the lowest-cost funds do not top the performance list. The top four had returns in excess of 20% year to date. That's decent, but not championship caliber.

Vanguard Total Stock Market ETF (VTI) and Vanguard S&P 500 (VOO) led that group with low 0.05% annual expense ratios. VTI's gain this year is 21.91%. VOO is up 20.69%. SPY has the fourth best expense ratio at 0.09% and a 20.54% gain.

So volume and expenses are only rough guides to performance leadership. Compare funds to peers tracking the same index to find your best choices for your goals and circumstances.Special Report: ETF StrategiesLooking for a top-performing ETF? ETF investors are typically affluent and experienced in the stock market. Given that only 3% of U.S. households own ETFs, the industry has its work cut out for it in educating retail investors about them.
Here are some of the biggest myths and truths about ETFs that investors must understand to avoid mistakes.

Myth No. 1: ETF liquidity doesn't matter and that only the liquidity of the underlying holdings matter. The truth is some thinly traded ETFs have very wide bid/ask spreads even if they hold very liquid stocks. The spread is the difference between the lowest price a trader is willing to sell the ETF and the highest price a buyer is willing to pay. The wider the spread, the bigger the immediate loss upon buying the ETF.
Dodd Kittsley, head of institutional product consulting at iShares, recommends investors use limit orders to get trades executed at the midpoint between bid and ask prices.

The analytics tool at ETF.com shows iPath Short Enhanced MSCI Emerging Markets ETN (EMSA) with less than $5 million in assets has a bid/ask spread that is nearly as big as the ETN's share price of 81.61. Most ETFs with bid/ask spreads larger than 1% of share price have less than $10 million in assets.

"Low-volume ETFs are disasters waiting to happen and in many cases have happened," said Ron Rowland, founder of Capital Cities Asset Management and AllStarInvestor.com in Austin, Texas. "Wide bid/ask spreads are just the most visible problem. The unseen problem is the inability to arbitrage the price of the ETF to its underlying NAV (net asset value)."

ETFs shares are created and redeemed through in-kind exchanges to prevent ETFs from trading at a discount or premium to their NAV. Market makers typically create and redeem ETFs in blocks of 50,000 shares, which thereby requires healthy trading volume.

But not all small, thinly traded ETFs have wide bid/ask spreads. IPath Inverse S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures ETN (XXV) has less than $4 million in assets but a bid/ask spread of 0.03%, which is the same as iShares Core S&P Small-Cap (IJR) with $13.5 billion in assets.
Myth No. 2: Thinking that due to diversification, ETFs are safer than stocks and can be bought and held with little volatility. The truth is some ETFs are as volatile as individual stocks.

"A blue Chip stock like Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) may have less market volatility compared to volatile sector ETFs like Market Vectors Gold Miners (GDX) or iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology (IBB)," Ron DeLegge, editor of ETFGuide.com said in an email. "On the other hand, a diversified health care ETF like Health Care Select Sector SPDR (XLV) may have less volatility compared to Johnson & Johnson. In comparing volatility, it's always important to do apples-with-apples measurements."

Myth No. 3: All ETFs are tax efficient. The truth: ETFs that hold futures contracts will issue a K-1 tax form instead of a 1099, which can be a hassle to deal with, notes ETF Database analyst Jared Cummans.

"Investors also often overlook the fact that two of the most popular funds, SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) and iShares Silver Trust (SLV) are taxed as collectibles," Cummans wrote. Capital gains on those are taxed at a maximum 28% rate instead of the ordinary 15%.
"ETFs linked to asset classes with high taxable income like REITs or Treasury bonds are best kept in tax-deferred accounts," DeLegge said.
High turnover in actively managed ETFs, which account for only 1% of all ETF assets, can potentially slap investors with capital gains distributions, said Kittsley of iShares.

Myth No. 4: The cheapest ETFs, including those offered with no commission, are always the best. The truth is some ETFs with commission-free trading have wide bid/ask spreads and so investors end up losing the difference between the bid/ask price when they trade.

"A low price tag can be attractive in the near term, but at the end of the day, you want to select ETFs that support your long-term investment goals as well as meet your cost threshold," Eric Pollackov, managing director of ETFs at Charles Schwab, said in an email.ETF investors are typically affluent and experienced in the stock market. Given that only 3% of U.S. households own ETFs, the industry has its work cut out for it in educating retail investors about them.Here are some of the biggest myths and truths about ETFs that investors must understand to avoid mistakes.Myth No. 1: ETF liquidity doesn't matter and that only the liquidity of the underlying holdings matter. A stronger U.S. dollar in the quarter is affecting diversified manufacturers Roper Industries (ROP) and Eaton (ETN), but both see promise in recent acquisitions.
Both also noted challenging macroeconomic conditions, but raised or affirmed full-year guidance.

Eaton, which makes truck drivetrains, hydraulics and aerospace components, reported adjusted first-quarter earnings of 84 cents per share, down 9% from a year ago, in part on the extra shares issued for $11.8 billion purchase of Cooper in November. That topped the 79-cents EPS analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected.

Revenue climbed 34% to $5.31 billion, under forecasts for $5.4 billion. Core sales fell 5%, and currency effects accounted for another 1% reduction. But recent acquisitions — mainly Cooper — more than offset that.
Eaton reaffirmed guidance for 2013 EPS between $4.05 and $4.45, with analysts expecting $4.35.

In a statement, Eaton CEO Alexander Cutler said results in 2013 "will depend more on our execution than on global growth. We are off to a great start this year, with our execution driving stronger than expected results in the first quarter."
Eaton shares popped 3.5% intraday on the stock market today.

Roper, which makes medical imaging equipment and industrial control and monitoring tools, said adjusted first-quarter earnings per share climbed 17% to $1.27, 5 cents more than analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected.
Revenue increased 4.2% to $740.7 million, though analysts were expecting $776.55 million.
It rang up record orders in the quarter, though its said conditions remained challenging.
Roper raised its full-year EPS guidance to a range of $5.76 to $5.94, from the earlier outlook of $5.60 to $5.82. Analysts expect $5.73 per share.

That new outlook factors in a boost from its $1 billion acquisition of Managed Health Care Associates, which provides equipment and services to pharmacies, acute-care facilities and other non-hospital medical settings. That deal should close this week, it said. The guidance also includes a negative currency impact of 5 cents per share.

Economist and best-selling author Robert Shiller, who developed the Case-Shiller Home Price Indexes, has rolled out an exchange traded note with Barclays Bank. The awkwardly named fund, Barclays ETN+ Shiller CAPE ETN (CAPE), tracks the Shiller Barclays CAPE US Core Sector Index. The ETN invests in the four most undervalued sectors among the nine S&P 500 sectors, based on their cyclically…
The Barclays iPath Coffee ETN (JO) spiked nearly 9% in heavy trade Tuesday, as coffee prices surged to 13-month highs after weekend rains in Brazil turned out to be much lighter than hoped.

Brazil, producer of a third of the world's coffee supply, started the year with its hottest January on record and its weakest rainfall in two decades. Tuesday's jump put Arabica coffee futures around $1.50 per pound, 49% above their November low. If growing regions don't see some relieving rains soon, some analysts project Arabica prices of $2 per pound.

Coffee-related businesses, including Starbucks (SBUX), Dunkin Donuts (DNKN) and Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), contract supplies well into the future, and aren't likely to be affected for two to three months, analysts say. Coffee price increases to consumers could potentially follow at that point.
The iPath Coffee ETN is up 22% so far in February, 40% year to date and 49% off its Nov. 6 low. On Tuesday, it moved to its highest mark in nine months.

Coffee prices toppled 23% last year in a third straight annual decline. The near-month contract for Arabica dropped to $1.01 a pound early in November, down 29% for the year and their lowest price since 2006. (Prices peaked at a 14-year high in May 2011.)

In November, indicators showed Brazil's crop off to a strong start. Experts were forecasting another record harvest. But by the start of January, Arabica prices had climbed to $1.22 and analysts were beginning to shave estimates on the crop.

At that point, Shawn Hackett, president of Hackett Financial Advisors in Boynton Beach, Fla., was calling a long-term bottom in coffee prices. Supplies were short of the lower-quality Robusta beans, forcing a shift to the higher-quality Arabica.
Hackett had forecast "a sizable Arabica deficit between now (early January) and the spring of 2014."

In a Feb. 4 report, Hackett projected that if February's dry spell persisted, Brazil's crop forecasts could be lowered as much as 10%. That supply pinch could push prices to $2 per pound, he said. In the long run, Hackett thinks Arabica prices will settle out at a much higher equilibrium than in the past.

"Coffee remains the best bull market in the whole commodity complex over the next five to ten years," he wrote.The Barclays iPath Coffee ETN (JO) spiked nearly 9% in heavy trade Tuesday, as coffee prices surged to 13-month highs after weekend rains in Brazil turned out to be much lighter than hoped.Brazil, producer of a third of the world's coffee supply, started the year with its hottest January on record and its weakest rainfall in two decades. Master limited partnerships, which typically run toll-road-type businesses transporting, storing and processing oil and gas, have exploded this year. They could be this year's big catch-up play after lagging the market last year. And if history repeats, they offer a compelling source of dividend income in a rising interest rate environment, analysts say. JPMorgan Alerian MLP Index ETN (AMJ) popped…

Stocks moved modestly higher in quiet trade Monday as merger deals took center stage.The S&P 500 rose 5%, the Nasdaq 4% and the Dow Jones Industrial average 3%. Volume was sharply lower, down 37% on the Nasdaq and 78% on the NYSE compared with the same time Friday, when options expiration boosted trading.Boeing (BA) rose 2%, the Dow's widest gain, after Argus upgrade the stock to buy. Micron Technology (MU) added 2%, while Netflix (NFLX) and Infosys (INFY) dropped 2% each.S&P 500 issue Cooper Industries (CBE) rocketed 25% after Eaton (ETN) said it would acquire the company in a deal valued at $11.8 billion. Cooper makes electrical power equipment and tools. Eaton, a diversified industrial operator based in Cleveland, said the merger would be immediately accretive to earnings and was expected to close before the end of the year. Eaton shares slipped a fraction.on the IBD 50, Web.com Group (WWWW) warmed 2%. The maker of website publishing software cleared a cup-with-handle base May 2, but may be facing some resistance near 16.Sturm Ruger (RGR) fell 6%, diving closer to a test of support at its 40-week moving average. The firearms maker cut its 10-week line in heavy trade May 8. A push above that line May 10-11 failed to hold above it. The stock is 32% off its May 1 high.Netease.com (NTES) slumped 3% in strong trade. The China-based maker of massive multi-player online role-playing games has had trouble pushing above resistance near 61.Ross Stores (ROST) slipped 2%, falling below its 10-week moving average. Canaccord Genuity downgraded the stock to hold from buy.

United States Agriculture Index Fund (USAG), tracking the SummerHaven Dynamic Agriculture Index Total Return, offers exposure to soybeans, corn, soft red winter wheat, hard red winter wheat, soybean oil, soybean meal, canola,…

Dividend-paying-stock fans embrace master limited partnerships, or MLPs, for their juicy yields. Global X Funds, best known for its foreign niche exchange traded funds, has rolled out a new MLP ETF that undercuts the large management fees these ETFs typically charge. Global X MLP ETF (MLPA), tracking the Solactive MLP Composite Index, holds 30 MLPs engaged in transportation, storage, processing,…

With interest rates hovering at record lows and expected to do so for the foreseeable future, dividend-paying funds have been all the rage with ETF providers. New York-based Yorkville ETF Advisors joined the party this week, rolling out Yorkville High Income MLP ETF (YMLP). The ETF tracks Structured Solutions' Solactive High Income MLP Index, which includes 25 selected master limited…
The "supply shock" erupting from the North American shale oil boom will have profound effects for global energy markets, says the International Energy Agency.

In its "Medium-Term Oil Market Report" released Tuesday, the IEA said the production onslaught will have impact on the oil market over the next five years as much as swelling Chinese demand did over the past 15 years. What's more, it will force companies to change how they transport, store and refine oil in addition to their investment strategies.
The IEA's announcement coincided with a rally in oil and gas exploration and production ETFs as investors bet the shale boom will certainly be a boon for some ETFs and a bust for others.
"Essentially the report corroborated what has been postulated in the market for the past year," Stephen Schork, founder of "The Schork Report," specializing in energy markets.
Key Facts From The Report
The report stated:
1. North American oil supply is projected to grow by 3.9 million barrels per day from 2012 to 2018, accounting for more than half of the (non-OPEC) increase.
2. Emerging markets are projected to overtake developed countries in oil product consumption by the second quarter of this year.
3. Developing countries, which accounted for 49% of global demand in 2012, will account for more than 54% by 2018.
4. The average cost of oil imports will fall from $109 a barrel in 2013 to $93 a barrel by 2018.
5. Global demand will rise from 89.78 million barrels a day in 2012 to 96.68 million barrels by 2018, up nearly 8%, assuming global economic growth of 3% to 4.5% annually.
6. Non-OPEC (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries) oil supplies are seen rising from 59.66 million barrels a day in 2012 to 66.30 million barrels by 2018, an 11% increase.
Here's a look at potential winners and losers in the stock market.
Major Oil Services Firms

The big winners of the shale boom will be major oil services and independent service operators, or ISOs, such as Schlumberger (SLB), Halliburton (HAL) and Baker Hughes (BHI), which have billion-dollar research and development budgets, says John Graves, author of "Fracking, America's Alternative Energy Revolution" and an asset manager based in Ventura, Calif.
All three companies are heavily overweighted in iShares Dow Jones U.S. Oil Equipment Index (IEZ), Market Vectors Oil Services ETF (OIH), which climbed 0.54% and 0.34%, respectively Tuesday.
Graves is also bullish on Exxon Mobil (XOM), BP (BP), Chevron (CVX) and Statoil (STO), which he believes have "the staying power to outlast regulatory or governmental interference."

IShares S&P North American Natural Resources (IGE), iShares Dow Jones U.S. Energy (IYE), Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE) and Vanguard Energy ETF (VDE) heavily overweight Exxon and Chevron and offer some exposure to Schlumberger and Halliburton. IGE, IYE, XLE and VDE jumped 0.96% to 1.42% Tuesday.

North Dakota and Montana are home to the 20th largest crude oil reserve in the world, said Schork, citing data from United States Geological Survey. This calls for expertise from unconventional, shale oil and Canadian oil sands producers, such as those found in Market Vectors Unconventional Oil & Gas (FRAK), up 1.02% Tuesday, and Sustainable North American Oil Sands (SNDS), up 0.18%.
Master Limited Partnerships

The North American shale oil boom not only impacts the economy and energy market but also related industries engaged in global transportation, storage and refining infrastructure, the IEA report said. U.S. midstream companies — most of which are Master Limited Partnerships, or MLPs — are boosting their transport and storage capacity in the U.S. to support the rising oil and gas supplies.

The most widely traded exchange traded product in this area is JPMorgan Alerian MLP Index ETN (AMJ), which fell 1.04% Tuesday. The drawback is that as an exchange traded note, investors have to rely on the issuer to make good on its debts and it doesn't actually hold the underlying stocks. It also currently trades at a premium to its net asset value because the issuer has limited the number of shares that can be created.
ALPS Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP), down 0.05% Tuesday, offers exposure to the underlying stocks but it is structured as a corporation, which means it has to pay taxes that take a bite out of total returns.
Transportation And Shipping

There will be a tremendous need for railroads to transport the oil and gas from the inland to the major ports for export, says Schork. IShares Dow Jones Transportation Average (IYT) offers more exposure to railroads than its competitor SPDR S&P Transportation (XTN), which is more heavily weighted in airlines and trucking.
Tanker shippers, found Guggenheim Global Shipping (SEA), will be re-routed. Instead of coming to the U.S. to import oil, they will be exporting oil from the U.S. to Asia, mainly China.
Coal

In the U.S., natural gas has displaced a third of coal usage at electric power plants in less than a decade and this trend will likely spread internationally, says Graves. This should explain why Market Vectors Coal ETF (KOL) has lost an average 15% a year the past five years.
Investment Risks
An onslaught of supply will most likely depress oil prices. Oil prices will sink an average of 5.5% between now and 2018, the IEA projects.

"As global refining capacity expansions outpace upstream supply growth, let alone demand growth, margins and utilization rates will come under pressure and higher-cost refineries will face increasingly strong competitive headwinds," the report said. "European refineries are at particularly high risk of closure over the forecast period (2012 to 2018)."

Investors without borders must be at least on their alert after the U.S. market, which slid badly Thursday, entered a correction. Most emerging-market bourses are already underwater, and can ill afford more losses.Ranking these markets from first to worst by year-to-date returns shows no emerging markets until the No. 7 slot.Nasdaq's 19.8% gain puts it at the top of the heap of the Daily World Map, which includes two U.S. indexes and 16 benchmark ETFs from around the world.Ishares MSCI Japan (EWJ) ETF places with a 16.9% improvement. Japan's stocks — and long-suffering economy — have won a huge boost from Abenomics.Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is delivering on his promise for huge fiscal and monetary stimulus actions. And his party's big win last month in elections for the upper house of Parliament (the Liberal Democratic Party already had control of the lower house) paves the way for more such action.The NYSE composite shows with a TK% rise.After that you'll find benchmark ETFs from France (up 11.6%), Germany (up 8.5%) and the U.K. (up 6.1%).That brings you to the No. 7 slot, which is held by iShares MSCI Hong Kong's (EWH) 1.1% gain.Maybe this qualifies as the highest-ranked emerging market return. While Hong Kong is a mature economy, it's also the gateway to mainland China. Most of the island's best stocks are of companies doing business in China.In any event, if a 1.1% gain is the best among emerging markets, one can't be impressed.Guggenheim China Small Cap (HAO) ETF shows a 0.3% rise. After that, the listings all show year-to-date losses.Wallowing on the bottom you'll find iShares MSCI Brazil (EWZ) ETF, off 22.1%, and second-worst is  Barclays iPath India (INP) ETN. Both countries are suffering through some political agonies and angry populations.Brazilians have been protesting — by the millions — against poor government services, stupefying red tape and a weak economy.India's much-ballyhooed reforms process has stalled and the economy is stuttering.The currency has been crashing, a victim of a bleeding currency-account deficit. The central bank was recently forced to tighten credit to protect the rupee, a move which bodes ill for this struggling giant.

Commodities — which have underperformed stocks the past two years owing to over-production and low demand — fronted a global stock sell-off Monday following news that China called for an urgent nationwide audit of government debt.That ignited fears that it may cut spending on infrastructure projects — the country's primary economic growth driver.IPath DJ-UBS Nickel ETN (JJN) crashed the hardest among non-leveraged ETFs, melting 5.42% to 18.41. It's tumbled 23% year to date and nearly 18% in the past 12 months. Some 40% of nickel supply, a key ingredient in stainless steel, is being produced at a loss at current prices, according to Deutsche Bank."Prices under $14,000 a metric ton are unsustainable for high-cost producers, meaning more production cuts are looming," IHS Global Insight's analysts wrote in a commodities report released Monday."Barring a significant shock, we see nickel prices bottoming out in the third quarter and moving incrementally higher into early 2014. Surplus conditions will keep prices below $18,000 a metric ton over the next six quarters."IPath DJ-UBS Copper ETN (JJC) was nearly flat at 38.10 — a three-week low. The ETF tracking the red metal has lost 17% year to date and 12% in the past year because of steady increases in mine production in the face of softening demand.Copper prices will likely rebound in the second half of 2013, pushing prices from $7,000 a metric ton to $7,500, according to IHS. "Recent mine accidents and tightness in scrap markets leads us to believe the market is a bit too pessimistic," IHS analysts wrote.IPath Pure Beta Grains ETN (WEET), tracking soybeans, corn, wheat, soybean meal and soybean oil, plunged 5.08% to 45.35 — a three-month low. It's tumbled 10% year to date and 18% in the past 12 months."They are moving south as it's recognized that growing conditions are good and better-than-expected crop yields are likely," David Hunter, chief market strategist at KCCI, a brokerage firm in Jersey City, N.J., said in an email.United States Natural Gas Fund (UNG) burned off 2.59% to 18.45 — a five-month low. It's lost 2.4% year to date and 11% in the past year. Natural gas has sold off the past two weeks after a sudden spike earlier this month as a heat wave struck the Northeast, boosting energy demand from increased use of air conditioners and fans.Natgas prices will likely rise as European liquefied natural gas supplies tighten in 2014, according to IHS. "Residential demand in Northwest Europe was 7 billion cubic meters higher than 2012 levels in the first five months of the year," IHS analysts wrote. "Power sector gas demand will contract slightly to 143 BCM in 2013, before rising slowly as power demand grows and coal capacity retires."Increased output in response to rising prices between 2008 and 2011 has been met with slow demand suggesting the global economy teeters on the edge of recession, some investing strategists say."China's credit crisis is worse than what we faced in 2008. Japan is in uncharted waters with what it is trying to do and policymakers could lose control of the situation," Hunter wrote."Europe continues very weak and the European Central Bank policy is not nearly easy enough," Hunter added. "Brazil and Australia are suffering due to the manufacturing slowdown in China and that's likely to get much worse."

2013: A Look Back And Ahead If you were stranded on an island and could only have four ETFs next year, which would they be? Several stock market strategists share their top ETF sector investment ideas for 2013.  Jeremy Held, director of research at ALPS Advisors in Denver, with $7.6 billion in assets under management: Energy Select Sector SPDR[ticker…
Some of last year's worst-performing exchange traded funds roared back to lead the first quarter.
Market Vectors India Small-Cap ETF (SCIF) and Market Vectors Egypt Index ETF (EGPT) spiked 34% each in the first quarter leading all nonleveraged ETFs.
But they're still a far cry from recovering their respective 55.8% and 51.7% crashes last year.
The benchmark iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) rose 12.4% in Q1 and the iShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking foreign developed markets, added 9.8%. SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) climbed 11.7%.
PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ), tracking the Nasdaq 100 index, vaulted 21.2%. SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) picked up 7.6%.

Investors embraced risky investments as the European Central Bank flushed money into its banking system — reducing fears of a global credit crisis — U.S. economic data beat expectations and inflation in emerging markets eased, said Alexander Young, global equity strategist at S&P Capital IQ.
"We had a real return to risk and that favors high-beta, exotic markets," Young said.
Investors looking for bargains bought into last year's hardest-hit markets.

"The pattern in 2010 and 2011 was for investors to pile into the previous year's losers for the first 10 weeks or so of the year and then take stock," said Cameron Brandt, director of research at EPFR Global. "That pattern seems to be playing out again."

India's economy grew 6.1% in the fourth quarter — the slowest pace in nearly three years — as high interest rates eroded consumer spending and investments. The Reserve Bank of India left the country's prime interest rate at 8.5% at its March 15 meeting to control inflation, which rose nearly 7% year over year in February, after topping 9% for most of 2011.
Inflation has been fueled by a 15% rise in Brent crude in a country that imports three-fourths of its oil, a weaker currency and a fiscal deficit.
Although SCIF made great headway this year, its chart turned bearish in late February. The ETF hit resistance at its 200-day moving average and rolled over. It fell 7.4% in March.

Egypt's stock market has posted the largest gain of any country this year after losing nearly half its value following the massive protests that overthrew President Hosni Mubarak. The most populous Arab country's economy grew only 1.2% last year and is expected to expand 1.8% this year amid 11% inflation.
Investing in Egypt holds many risks, owing to political division over the new constitution, a coming presidential election and the currency possibly losing value.

EGPT has been consolidating above the key 200-day line for nearly two months. It's unclear whether it's taking a breather after a strong run-up or resuming last year's downtrend. It fell nearly 10% in March.

Market Vectors Vietnam ETF (VNM) rallied 30.7% year to date. It plunged 43.8% in 2011 (vs. a 23% decline for the MSCI Emerging Markets index) as the Southeast Asian country's inflation rate spiked to 19%. Vietnam's market rebounded in the first quarter as inflation moderated and the central bank started to cut interest rates, says Carl Delfeld, editor of PacificRimConfidential.com.
"Foreign investment in manufacturing is picking up and overall manufacturing wages are half that of China," Delfeld said.

Vietnam's economy expanded 5.8% last year and is forecast to grow 6.3% in 2012. Inflation is expected to taper to 12%. The socialist nation struggles with becoming a market-oriented economy, a depreciating currency, a growing trade deficit, budget deficits, a shortage of skilled labor and widespread poverty.
VNM's chart action looks bullish. It broke above the key 200-day moving average in late February and has been consolidating in a sideways range for most of March.
Biggest ETF Losers

ETFs tracking market volatility — which tends to move opposite the market — led losers as the VIX, the Chicago Board Options Exchange Market Volatility Index, fell near a 52-week low. The ETFs cratered 20% to 60% in the first quarter. VelocityShares Daily Inverse VIX ST ETN (XIV), which rises when volatility falls, rocketed 84%. High VIX readings mean investors believe the market will move sharply higher or lower. Low VIX readings suggest investors believe the probability that the market will move significantly up or down is low.

"I think general apathy from the media and retail investors along with rising prices has resulted in low volatility," said Simon Maierhofer, co-founder of ETFGuide.com. "And trading volume is the lowest it's been in almost a decade."

Daniel K. Weiskopf, chief investment officer at Global ETF Strategies, is watching iPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures ETN (VXX), iPath S&P 500 VIX Mid-Term Futures ETN (VXZ), iPath S&P 500 Dynamic VIX ETN (XVZ) and Barclays S&P 500 Dynamic VEQTOR ETN (VQT) for possible reversals.
"Predicting when volatility will pick up has many challenges, but at current price levels complacency seems to be overwhelming fear," said Weiskopf.

Volatile trading in VelocityShares 2x Long VIX Short Term ETN (TVIX) sparked a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation.
