While some Asian stock indexes are bouncing back, the lagging Nikkei can get lost in the shuffle. Yet for the first time in years, a number of stocks from that long-suffering economy are starting to shine. Japan's relative weakness is more clearly seen when looking at IBD's Daily World Map. IShares MSCI Japan (EWJ) has lost 3.8% year to date.…

The stock market volatility of late puts into question how much longer the current uptrend can last. Dividend-paying ETFs can cushion the blow of day-to-day gyrations and offer investors something for sitting on their hands. Here's a look at five of the fattest-dividend paying ETFs on the market and what's driving there performance. With the exception of iShares FTSE NAREIT…

The stock market sell-off that started in September has spared very few stocks or ETFs. But there are a few defying the swoon that are also paying juicy dividends, rewarding investors to sit on their hands.Here's an overview of five ETFs yielding 7% or more that are also trading above their 200-day moving averages, unlike some of the major indexes.1. Peritus High Yield ETF (HYLD) 12-month yield: 8.37%. Annual expenses: 1.35%.HYLD has returned 11.85% year to date vs. 4.31% for the benchmark Barclays U.S. Aggregate Bond index, putting it No. 1 in its Morningstar category.Actively managed by Peritus I Asset Management, the fund buys noninvestment grade bonds — commonly referred to as junk bonds — that are trading below face value. This allows for potential price appreciation on top of the yield income.Peritus says it shuns credit ratings from the rating agencies in favor of its own research. It prefers buying bonds issued by companies that offer an "essential product or service," generate free cash flow and have hard assets not priced into the bonds.2. UBS E-TRACS Wells Fargo Business Development Company ETN (BDCS) 12-month yield: 7.08%. Annual expenses: 0.85%.BDCS has surged 27.30% year to date vs. 12.57% for the S&P 500. This exchange traded note tracks an index of 28 companies engaged in lending to small and midsized companies at high interest rates while also buying stakes in the companies. They may also get involved in managing the company.The top holdings in Wells Fargo Business Development Company Index and their respective index weightings:1. Ares Capital (ARCC) 10.16%.2. Prospect Capital (PSEC) 9.86%.3. American Capital (ACAS) 8.74%.4. Apollo Investment (AINV) 8.07%.5. Fifth Street Finance (FSC) 6.68%.6. Solar Capital (SLRC) 6.60%.7. BlackRock Kelso Capital (BKCC) 5.52%.8. PennantPark Investment (PNNT) 4.57%.9. Main Street Capital (MAIN) 4.33%.10. Triangle Capital (TCAP) 3.97%.As an exchange traded note, BDCS is an unsecured debt obligation issued by UBS. Its value may be affected by changes in UBS' credit worthiness. If UBS defaults, investors could lose all of their money.3. UBS E-TRACS 2X Wells Fargo Business Development Company ETN (BDCL) 12-month yield: 13.22%. Annual expenses: 0.85%.BDCL doubles the daily price movements and pays twice the yield of BDCS.4. SPDR Barclays Capital High Yield Bond (JNK) 12-month yield: 6.89%. Annual expenses: 0.40%.JNK has returned 10.45% year to date. High-yield bonds make higher interest payments because the issuing companies have low credit quality or they're highly leveraged or indebted, which increases the risk of default or bankruptcy. But an ETF with 279 holdings minimizes the impact of defaults.The default rate in 2009 was about 13% and fell to 3.3% by the end of 2010. On a trailing 12-month basis the current high-yield default rate was only 2.2% as of July 2012, according to Morningstar."Disruptions in the bond markets have caused this fund to experience significant swings in the premium and discounts to its net asset value (NAV)," Timothy Strauts, an analyst at Morningstar wrote. "While we believe that the problems actually lie in the markets of the underlying securities, investors should be aware of the premium or discount to NAV before purchasing this fund and be prepared to handle the gyrations."JNK's correction during the recent sell-off has been very mild compared with the market. It's now trading only 1% below its 52-week high, while the market has fallen 6% off its multiyear peak.Investors have piled into bonds in search of dividend income as interest rates hover at record lows. Should rates rise, bond prices will fall. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.A major risk is that in bear markets, high-yield bonds can collapse just as badly as stocks. High-yield bond prices and spreads fluctuate with the market's expectations of high-yield issuers defaulting.5. iShares iBoxx $ High Yield Corporate Bond (HYG) 12-month yield: 6.78%. Annual expenses: 0.50%.HYG holds an index of junk bonds just like JNK. Its portfolio is nearly three times bigger with more than 600 bonds.

2013: A Look Back And AheadWe asked investment strategists to share their top commodity ETFs bets for the New Year. Their picks: Viktoria Palushaj, market analyst at CitrinGroup in Birmingham, Mich., with $60 million in assets under management: iPath Dow Jones UBS Copper Total Return Sub-Index ETN (JJC).Copper prices reached near a two-month high of $8,140 a ton on Dec. 10, following news that industrial production in China — the world's top consumer of the industrial metal — grew strongly at an annual rate of 10.1% in November.While China's export-dependent economy continues to struggle with weak demand from key Western markets, its manufacturing sector has avoided contracting in the past few months as a result of the $157 billion infrastructure spending bill passed in September.China consumes about 40% of global copper output. So the government's commitment to construction and manufacturing will support copper prices next year. Also, g lobal copper demand in 2013 is expected to grow 3.4% over 2012 to 20.85 million tons. It's estimated that China alone will use 8.1 million tons.Beyond China, strong demand is expected from Japan and Brazil. Japan continues to rebuild from last year's natural disasters, passing a fiscal stimulus bill this year to be partly used on public works projects, while Brazil plans to invest more than $30 billion over the next five years to improve its roads and railways.With significant efforts and resources dedicated to infrastructure improvements, copper consumption should outstrip supply next year.One limitation to copper's appreciation may be on the supply side. China — the world's leading producer of refined copper — is expected to expand its mining capacity in the second half of 2013, which may lead to an oversupply. Still, demand growth combined with expected continued Federal Reserve easing are likely to support metals such as copper all year. Ron Fernandes, CEO of Avatar Investment Management in Stamford, Conn., with $800 million in assets under management: Market Vectors Coal ETF (KOL).Coal is an under-loved commodity within the energy sector. Low natural gas prices and a slowdown in China reduced demand and drove valuations down in 2012.However, natural gas prices are rebounding, China has stabilized, India is showing signs of life. Commodities are powering up and emerging markets are poised for continued solid growth in 2013.Four countries — China, India, Australia and Indonesia — generate more than 60% of the total world output. China alone produces 40%. The U.S., perceived by many as a leading producer, comes in at roughly 15% of total production.Global demand is expected to grow at 5% annualized over the next decade, more than offsetting the cut in U.S.-based demand. That steady growth will make both China and India — the first- and second-largest global populations — net importers of coal and provide an opportunity for U.S.-headquartered producers to build a lucrative export-driven model. KOL has little downside risk with potential to deliver a 25% return in 2013. Nick Brooks, head of research and investment strategy at ETF Securities in London, with $29.5 billion in assets under management: ETFS White Metals Basket Trust (WITE), tracking platinum, palladium and silver.White precious metals like platinum, palladium and silver, which have significant industrial usage, could benefit even as ongoing economic uncertainty is exacerbated by potential policy mistakes from global governments.Nearly 60% of the combined demand for platinum and palladium is from the auto sector. Platinum group metals (PGMs) are crucial components for autocatalyst production. PGM prices have been buoyed by improvement in U.S. and Chinese growth and ongoing mining strikes and unrest in South Africa, which accounts for about three-quarters of global output.Palladium has outperformed platinum recently, with eurozone weakness weighing on platinum's European diesel auto demand prospects. Palladium has the potential to further outperform given its more direct gearing to rising U.S. and China auto demand — though futures positioning appears quite stretched and needs to be watched carefully.While silver has returned 12% over 2012, its subdued performance in recent weeks appears to have more to do with its continued strong links to gold than its demand profile for 2013. Like gold, silver has historically been used as a currency. As the ongoing flood of liquidity from central banks threatens to erode the value of global reserve currencies, silver can provide a potential alternative investment. With over half of its demand coming from industry, mainly electronics, silver has significant upside potential if the nascent rebound in global growth continues. Adrian Day, president of Adrian Day Asset Management in Annapolis, Md. , with $170 million in assets under management: SPDR Gold Trust (GLD).The primary driver of gold has been easy monetary policy, which is positive for gold. The Federal Reserve is both "printing" money and keeping interest rates low. The recent QE4 (fourth round of quantitative easing) of buying $85 billion in bonds each month has increased the pace of money growth. Monetary policy in fact is easy around the world and likely to stay so.In Japan, the new government is committed to a more accommodative policy and the new governor of the Bank of England has indicated he wants an even easier policy. In Europe, the stage is set for the European Central Bank to begin buying sovereign bonds with newly created money.At the same time, global interest rates remain low. In a majority of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, real rates are negative. Short-term rates are lower than forecasted inflation. That is positive for gold.The major risk for gold would be tightening monetary policy, including significantly higher rates, which seems unlikely for the foreseeable future.In China, investment demand slipped marginally in mid-year after a strong first quarter as the economy slowed. But anecdotal evidence of record exports of gold from Hong Kong to the mainland suggest gold exports are rising.China's demand represents between 15% and 20% of world investment demand. Jewelry demand continues to increase as the economy and middle class grow. Last year, 516 tons of gold jewelry were sold in China, up from 400 the year before. India's jewelry demand has dropped from 746 tons in 2010 to just 516 last year, and this year is likely to have dropped below China's. It is unlikely there will be any significant increase in supply, absent any unexpected sales from U.S. stockpiles or other major stockpiles at the IMF (International Monetary Fund), Germany or France. Supply is expected to grow a modest 1% to 1.5% in 2013. Global gold production still remains below the levels of the early 2000s, at the beginning of this bull market.

India's HDFC Bank (HDB) can boast solid annual earnings growth and an attractive chart. But perhaps its greatest plus these days is that it's based in India.HDFC Bank is shaping a flat base with a buy point at 39.42. The correction within the base is a remarkably shallow 8%. Volume appears mostly tame.This pattern is HDB's third base this year. The first two didn't go anywhere — either way. Thus, the latest pattern is a first-stage base, which is of lesser risk.More importantly, the last two bases were far more attractive than the first, a cup-with-handle that ran 33% deep.Also impressively, HDFC Bank's current flat base is appearing while the broad market is in a correction. This counter-trend stability is reflected by a rising Relative Strength line.HDFC Bank's earnings do not stand out as a typical superstar's record. The past four quarters saw EPS gains of 10%, 13%, 29% and 19%.Full-year estimates are running at a 24% increase for fiscal 2013 earnings and a 27% increase in 2014. Its years end in March.The company issues a small dividend, which amounts to a 0.6% yield on an annualized basis.The big story in India is the new effort by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to loosen some controls in this highly regulated and closed-to-outsiders economy.Most of Singh's moves need no approvals from Parliament, but some face lots of resistance from entrenched domestic interests.The first move was to raise diesel prices — heavily subsidized and regulated — by 12%. That was followed by lowering the barriers to foreign investment in some industries, including domestic airlines, power, retail and finance.The bulk of Singh's bold move was announced Sept. 14. The Bombay Stock Exchange's benchmark Sensitive index has climbed 3.6% since the close of Sept. 13. To compare, the S&P 500 has fallen 5.5%.Barclays iPath India (INP) ETN shows a 21.4% year-to-date gain. That puts it in first place on IBD's Daily World Map. On a 12-month-return basis, Barclays iPath India shows just a 1% gain and stands in 14th place.India's surge the past few months has been almost meteoric, compared to other major markets.IBD's foreign banks industry group holds a poor 98th place out of the 197 industries tracked by IBD, as of Monday's edition.But note that the group is rising. It stood in 154th place just eight weeks ago. Its climb since then has been steady if unspectacular.HDFC Bank holds the No. 2 slot within the group by Composite Rating. Another India name, Icici Bank (IBN), is in fourth place.

Airlines soared but exchange traded funds mostly fell in quiet trade Wednesday as the markets took in mixed economic data. Business inventories in the U.S. rose by 0.4% in April, topping a 0.3% expected increase as well as March's reading. That could be because of lower consumer demand or that businesses expect future sales growth. Wholesale prices in May fell…
ETF investors are starting to pour into coffee. After dripping a whopping 30% this year, a fresh bull market in the commodity could be brewing, a commodity expert says.
IPath DJ-UBS Coffee Subindex Total Return SM Index ETN (JO) rose 0.5% Tuesday, after gapping up 2.6% Monday. A more thinly traded note, iPath Pure Beta Coffee ETN (CAFE) surged 0.8% Tuesday.
On the NYMEX, coffee for December delivery traded at $1.67 a pound Tuesday. Coffee for July 2014 delivery traded at $1.90 a pound, which suggests traders expect more scarcity in the future.

The rally Monday was mainly driven by short covering due to fears Hurricane Isaac would disrupt shipments from South and Central America into New Orleans, the earthquake in El Salvador and traders closing out positions ahead of the Federal Reserve's scheduled speech Friday, said Jack Scoville, vice president of the PRICE Futures Group, a Chicago-based brokerage.
"Fed meetings excite people to get out of shorts and head to the sidelines," he said.
Bull Market Brewing

Shawn Hackett, president of Hackett Financial Advisors in Boynton Beach, Fla., sent out a special alert to his clients last weekend recommending coffee as a buy. He projects coffee will reach $2.50 a pound over the next 12 months and $4 a pound over the next two years.

Heavy rains this summer in Brazil damaged Arabica coffee crops and caused trees to bloom prematurely, hurting their ability to flower and grow buds abundantly, Hackett wrote. As the world's largest coffee producer, the South American country accounts for about a third of all global supply. He expects Brazil to produce 45 million bags next year, 10 million fewer than this year.

"Also, the likelihood of El Nino-reduced Robusta crops in Vietnam and Indonesia next year will further exacerbate this impending supply squeeze," Hackett wrote. Commercial traders — the so-called smart money — have loaded up on coffee contracts. Hackett says he hasn't seen them this bullish since 2003 and 2008.
"Both times preceded fantastic multiyear bull market moves," Hackett wrote.
The dollar-denominated commodity has been rising like most others, owing to the greenback's weakness on expectations of more quantitative easing.
Investment Risks

The biggest risk to buying commodities is a recession, which would weaken demand. Bag counts from producers are "notoriously unreliable," says Mark Garrigues, an independent commodities trader. It's in the producers' best interest to keep supply data secret.
In his 25 years trading coffee, he's noticed the market tends to find new supply when nominal prices reach $2.75 to $3 a pound.

Commodities markets suffer from "price contamination," in which suppliers withhold shipments because prices have increased since they signed the contract. There's always a risk that the coffee won't make it to the port or get shipped on time, Garrigues says.
Technical View
JO has slumped 30% year to date and 45% in the past 12 months. JO trades below both its 50- and 200-day moving averages, which is very bearish.

So far it appears to be staging a countertrend rally in a downtrend that started in May 2011. Its IBD Accumulation-Distribution Rating declined from an A to C over the past six weeks, which is bearish. Its Relative Strength Rating is a very low 10 on a scale of 1 to 99.

As an ETN, JO is a debt note that tracks cocoa and coffee futures prices synthetically. It doesn't own actual contracts in the underlying commodity. Investors must trust the issuers to deliver those returns, which can be affected by the issuer's credit quality.

PowerShares DB Agriculture Fund (DBA) tracks 11 different commodities contracts, holds a 7.5% weighting in coffee. Global X FTSE Greek ETF  (GREK) surged 8% in four times normal volume Friday as German Chancellor Angela Merkel prepared to visit Athens next week to discuss with the prime minister ways to solve the country's debt crisis.

It will be her first visit to Greece since 2007, before the debt crisis started. Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said Friday that the country will run out of money by next month if the next round of bailout money isn't received.

Greek union leaders led protests outside parliament over Merkel's visit. The unions said in a statement that "workers, pensioners and unemployed people can take no more of the European Union's punitive policies," AP reported.

GREK's gain Friday brought the week's advance to 16%. Friday's action was a breakout above a 16.10 buy point in a deep, cup-with-handle pattern. The top of the handle is 20% below the top of the pattern. Breakouts work best when they occur within 15% of the high.
GREK has a Relative Strength Rating of 78 and an Accumulation-Distribution Rating of A.

Elsewhere in Europe, iShares MSCI Italy (EWI) rose 1% for a weekly gain of 6%. EWI's RS Rating is a low 54, and its Acc-Dis Rating is a neutral C. But it found support at its 10-week line, which just crossed above its 40-week line this week, both constructive moves.

Among other big gainers Friday, several China ETFs gained 1% to 3% as the country ended a one-week holiday centered on the Oct. 1 National Day. The advance came amid worries about an economic slowdown and hopes of impending stimulus action when the new government is installed in November. Global X China Materials  (CHIM) vaulted 2%, Global X China Consumer (CHIQ) 2% and iShares FTSE China 25 (FXI) 1%.
PowerShares Dynamic Financials (PFI) leapt 2%.
On the losing end, coffee slumped 3% or more. IPath Coffee ETN (JO) plunged 4% and iPath Pure Beta Coffee ETF (CAFE) fell 3%.

SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) was nearly flat in afternoon trade Friday, ending the week with a gain of about 1%. PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), which tracks the 100 largest nonfinancial stocks in the Nasdaq, was nearly flat for the day and week.

IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), which tracks developed foreign markets, was flat for the day and up 2% for the week. Global X China Materials  (CHIM) vaulted 2%, Global X China Consumer (CHIQ) 2% and iShares FTSE China 25 (FXI) 1%.PowerShares Dynamic Financials (PFI) leapt 2%.On the losing end, coffee slumped 3% or more. IPath Coffee ETN (JO) plunged 4% and iPath Pure Beta Coffee ETF (CAFE) fell 3%.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) was nearly flat in afternoon trade Friday, ending the week with a gain of about 1%. PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), which tracks the 100 largest nonfinancial stocks in the Nasdaq, was nearly flat for the day and week.IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), which tracks developed foreign markets, was flat for the day and up 2% for the week. IShares MSCI Emerging Markets (EEM) was flat Friday and up 1% for the week.

In a "View by" option, you can sort ETFs by the most important fundamental and technical indictors: price, percent change, Accumulation-Distribution Rating, Relative Strength Rating, dividend yield and volume. (Please see the Five Most Important Technical Indicators For ETFs story for more information about Accumulation-Distribution and RS Ratings.)
In the primary "View by" option, you can sort an ETF by price, price change, price percentage change, volume and volume change.
Also, you can open its chart in MarketSmith, a sister service available at Investors.com.

The enhanced ETF Center sorts ETFs by major categories: U.S. equity, sectors, global equities, fixed income, commodities and currencies. It features a screen for the biggest winners and losers over the week, month, three months, six months and year. It also includes a screen for ETFs that are building bases and ones that just broke out.
It screens from the 350 most widely traded and liquid ETFs listed in IBD's ETF performance tables in the print edition.
This will let you find the most highly rated and best-performing ETFs in five major categories.

In the "ETF Bases" screen Oct. 17, iShares MSCI Netherlands (EWN) sported the highest RS and Accumulation-Distribution Ratings combination (78 and B-). EWN has formed a bullish, cup-with-handle pattern and is trading above its key 50- and 200-day moving averages. It's trading near a 52-week high. It's returned 13.2% year to date vs. 11.3% for the MSCI EAFE Index, the benchmark for foreign developed markets. It's up 6.3% in the past year vs. 6.3% for the EAFE.

Schwab US REIT ETF (SCHH) had the lowest RS and Accumulation-Distribution Rating of 32 and D-. It's consolidating below its 50-day line and trades 5% below its 52-week high. SCHH has returned 12.9% year to date and 19.1% in the past 12 months vs. 14.4% and 17.4% for the SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) over the same periods.

In the "ETF Just Out of Bases" screen, Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR (XLY) turned up as the most highly rated nonleveraged, long ETF, with a 72 RS and B Accumulation-Distribution. XLY has vaulted 18.5% year to date and 19.1% over the past year. In the past three months, it's climbed 7.5% vs. 6.1% for SPY.

IShares Dow Jones US Home Construction (ITB) floated to the top of the Sector/Industry list with an eye-popping 95 RS and B Accumulation-Distribution. It's been in a steady uptrend all year, returning a whopping 72.6% year to date and 94.9% the past year.

PowerShares Emerging Markets Sovereign Debt (PCY) topped the Bond/Income ETFs list with a fat 4.7% yield, 69 RS and A+ Accumulation-Distribution. PCY returned 18.8% year to date vs. a paltry 3.7% for the benchmark Barclays U.S. Aggregate Bond index. PCY gained 21.0% the past 12 months vs. 5.0% for the benchmarks.

In screening commodities, iPath DJ-UBS Grains ETN (JJG) turned up with the highest RS and Accumulation-Distribution Ratings of 75 and C-. JJG has rallied 30.3% year to date and 27.3% in the past year.

Spain outpaced global markets Friday as the government pushed to have European rescue funds go directly to its battered banks instead of through the government so that they wouldn't be added to the country's mounting debt.
Under current rules of the proposed 100 billion euro bailout ($125 billion), the public would be on the hook if the banks don't repay their loans and thereby burden the country with new debt.

IShares MSCI Spain Index (EWP) rallied 4.14%. EWP has been rising for three weeks straight, surging 14% from its nine-year low. That's not enough to meet the 20% jump off a bottom that to some technical analysts signals a fresh bull market. The rise, thus far, is viewed as a countertrend rally in a long downtrend.

The proposed bailout increases the risk of investing in Spain rather than reducing it because it would add to the public's debt burden, says Komal S. Sri-Kumar, chief global strategist at TCW. Spain's public debt-to-gross domestic product ratio was 67% at the end of 2011. The bailout, when completed, would push the ratio up as much as 15 percentage points to more than 80%.

Spain's banking crisis has morphed into a vicious cycle in which weakness in its financial system entices depositors to pull their savings out and store their money in German or U.K. banks, compounding the weakness in Spanish banks.
"The pressure on Spanish and Italian banking systems will increase. In turn, that would likely prompt additional capital flight," Sri-Kumar wrote.
Market Overview
In afternoon trade the SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) rose 0.63% to 133.26.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) climbed 0.55%.
PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the 100 largest nonfinancial stocks on the Nasdaq, increased 0.73%.
IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking developed foreign markets, advanced 0.80%.
IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) added 0.40%. Both EFA and EEM plummeted nearly 5% the prior session.
Technical Overview

SPY, QQQ and DIA all dropped below key-price support at their 50-day moving averages the prior session with more than 90% trading volume to the downside. The sell-off prompted Simon Maierhofer, co-founder of ETFGuide.com, to close his long positions and go short, to profit from falling prices.
"This may be the shakeout decline — leading to higher prices — but the odds suggest this may be the real deal next leg down," Maierhofer wrote in this daily technical forecast.

The S&P 500 is trapped in a trading range between 1200 and 1400, or $120 to $140 for the SPY, potentially for the rest of the year, says Mark D. Arbeter, chief technical strategist at S&P Capital IQ. Crude oil and copper may have found a bottom and their rebound could push stocks higher, he wrote in his weekly technical report.

Traders' sentiment in crude is the most bearish it's been in three years. The Commitment of Traders report shows that producers or the so-called "smart money" are net long oil while the speculators or so-called "dumb money" have cut their exposures, suggesting that oil prices are due for a bounce, he says.
Fund Flows

ETF and mutual fund flows show that investors expect a new round of quantitative easing and are opting for risk assets in the face of all the troubling news globally, including slowing growth in China and Germany, Spain's banking crisis, U.S. corporate profit warnings and weak economic data in the U.S., EPFR Global said.
It reported in its weekly fund flow release for the week ending June 20:
1. Stock funds overall posted back-to-back weekly inflow for the first time since mid-March.
2. Redemptions from U.S. investment grade bonds hit a 13-week high.
3. Mortgage-backed-bonds took in fresh money for the 67th straight week.

4. Emerging-markets stock funds saw outflow for the sixth time in seven weeks as concerns about Asia offset optimism that European and U.S. policymakers will take more steps to stimulate their economies in the second half of 2012.
5. Canada, U.S., Japan and Germany stock funds all recorded inflow in excess of $650 million.
6. Europe stock funds saw their fifth straight week of outflow. But the total was offset by $869 million going into Germany stock funds.
7. Global stock funds had their biggest inflow year to date as they extended their current winning streak to four straight weeks.
8. Gold and precious metals fund inflow hit a 20-week high and accounted for all the inflow recorded by commodities-sector funds.
9. Europe bond funds saw ouflow of $886 million.
10. Emerging market local currency funds posted their biggest inflow since the fourth week of March.

Major exchange traded funds rebounded from oversold levels after selling off in the morning on a U.S. factory orders report that showed a surprise drop.

Orders for goods produced in U.S. factories dropped 0.6% in April, the Commerce Department said Monday. Economists had expected a rise of 0.1%. March orders were revised to show an even bigger decline.

In late afternoon trading, the SPDR S&P 500  (SPY) fell 3 cents to 128.13, still below its 200-day moving average after closing below that key level on Friday. It's tumbled 10% from its multi-year peak in April, signaling a technical correction.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) fell 0.2%.
PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the largest-100 non-financial stocks on the Nasdaq, added 0.2%.

Foreign markets bounced back from oversold levels as bargain hunters supported prices. iShares MSCI EAFE Index  (EFA), tracking developed foreign markets, added 0.8%. iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index  (EEM) rose 0.4%.
Some asset financial gurus say stocks have fallen to bargain prices that investors should embrace.

"The S&P 500 is trading at approximately 13 times forward earnings, which is more than 20% cheaper than October 2007 levels," Ethan Anderson, chief investment strategist at Rehmann in Grand Rapids, Minn., told clients in a note. "Second, corporate balance sheets, especially those of financial institutions, are cash heavy due to lessons learned in 2008."

Emerging markets are even cheaper, trading at nine times forward earnings estimates. But low valuations in the absence of positive growth catalysts could be a value trap, says Alec Young, global equity strategist at S&P Capital IQ.

"They reflect the very real possibility of continued downside surprises to U.S., European and BRIC growth rates as well as the potential for a major negative credit event in Europe as its crisis continues to spiral out of control," Young said in a client note Monday. "Amidst this deteriorating macro-economic backdrop, consensus earnings per share revisions have recently been negative for Europe, Canada, Australia, China, India and Brazil, suggesting to us that greater confidence in future growth is needed to spark lasting price-to-earnings expansion."

He warned, however, any positive news out of Europe could spark a short-covering rally in which short sellers have to buy back stocks to close out their positions, thereby driving up prices. And a counter-trend rally would be short-lived.
Biggest Gainers

iPath U.S. Treasury Long Bond Bull ETN  (DLBL) surged 4.11%, outpacing the non-leveraged ETF universe. The note tracks increases and decreases in the yield of long-dated U.S. Treasury bonds. The 10-year bond yield rose 0.055% to 1.524% as prices eased from overbought levels. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Investors flocked to Treasuries as a safe haven but this may prove dangerous once rock-bottom interest rates bounce back from record lows, says Peter Schiff, CEO of Euro Pacific Capital.

"There is no way to justify record low-interest rates in this country given our atrocious fiscal position," Schiff wrote. "I believe interest rates here should approach levels comparable to the more indebted European countries.
"Once it becomes obvious just how many dollars the Fed is prepared to print to stave off recession, people running into treasuries today will likely suffer buyer's remorse."

Global X Funds, best known for its niche emerging market ETFs, has rebranded one of its ETFs to play global small-cap miners.

Global X S&P/TSX Venture 30 Canada ETF was converted into Global X Junior Miners ETF (JUNR) and tracks a new index, the Solactive Junior Miners Index. It includes 96 companies that dig up gold, silver, copper, iron, nickel, titanium and other basic materials.

"As large miners exhaust existing resources, junior miners are often poised to explore, develop and monetize new mines to bring additional supply to the market," Global X said in a statement. "Investors may also benefit from increased merger and acquisition activity in the sector, as large mining companies look to acquisitions and partnerships as additional sources of supply and geographic expansion."
Stocks come from more than 10 countries including Canada, weighted 34%, Australia 26%, the U.S. 18%, the U.K. 7% and China 4%.
JUNR will compete with SPDR S&P Metals & Mining (XME), EGShares Emerging Markets Metals & Mining ETF (EMT) and numerous other metal specific mining ETFs.
Metals and miners ETFs rallied sharply last week after the Chinese government announced new infrastructure projects to create railways, roads and airports to lift economic growth.
"Let's face it, hard assets are finite and the supply decreases every day while the global demand increases daily," said Anthony Welch, a partner at Sarasota Capital Strategies in Osprey, Fla.
"Lower supply and higher demand equal higher prices — the first lesson of any economics class." He believes all portfolios should have some long-term holdings in basic materials.
New RBS Alternator Note
The Royal Bank of Scotland has rolled out a new exchange traded note that tracks an index that switches in and out of three ETFs.

RBS US Large Cap Alternator Exchange Traded Notes (ALTL) offers the returns generated from rotating between the S&P 500 Total Return Index, the S&P 500 Low Volatility Total Return Index and the S&P 500 Equal Weight Total Return Index based on relative strength.

The indexes are scored based on their performance over the past one, three, six, nine and 12 months. The fund holds the index with the highest score every month. The logic is that the low volatility index will outperform the S&P 500 during bear and volatile markets, the prospectus states.

The equal-weighted index has the same exposure to all companies in the index, while benchmark S&P 500 Total Return is market-cap weighted and has more exposure to the largest companies. The equal weighted index will likely be more volatile than the benchmark because it has more exposure to small-cap stocks.

Rick Ferri, founder of Portfolio Solutions in Troy, Mich., is skeptical about this fund. "They have back tested the index-flipping strategy and tortured the data until it confessed to adding alpha (returns)," Ferri said. "How can any company issue a fund that didn't hypothetically beat the market?"
Ferri also doesn't like that it's an exchange traded note, which is a debt obligation issued by the firm. Changes in the company's creditworthiness may affect the ETN's value.

The ETN charges an annual management fee of 1% of assets.Global X Funds, best known for its niche emerging market ETFs, has rebranded one of its ETFs to play global small-cap miners.Global X S&P/TSX Venture 30 Canada ETF was converted into Global X Junior Miners ETF (JUNR) and tracks a new index, the Solactive Junior Miners Index. It includes 96 companies that dig up gold, silver, copper, iron, nickel, titanium and other basic materials."As large miners exhaust existing resources, junior miners are often poised to explore, develop and monetize new mines to bring additional supply to the market," Global X said in a statement. "Investors may also benefit from increased merger and acquisition activity in the sector, as large mining companies look to acquisitions and partnerships as additional sources of supply and geographic expansion."Stocks come from more than 10 countries including Canada, weighted 34%, Australia 26%, the U.S. 18%, the U.K. 7% and China 4%.JUNR will compete with SPDR S&P Metals & Mining (XME), EGShares Emerging Markets Metals & Mining ETF (EMT) and numerous other metal specific mining ETFs.Metals and miners ETFs rallied sharply last week after the Chinese government announced new infrastructure projects to create railways, roads and airports to lift economic growth."Let's face it, hard assets are finite and the supply decreases every day while the global demand increases daily," said Anthony Welch, a partner at Sarasota Capital Strategies in Osprey, Fla."Lower supply and higher demand equal higher prices — the first lesson of any economics class." Corporations are scaling back investment, hiring and inventories ahead of steep year-end tax hikes and spending cuts, the most concrete sign to date that uncertainty over the so-called fiscal cliff is already hurting the anemic economy.

The automatic, draconian provisions were meant to prod lawmakers to reach their own deficit-cutting deal. But everything's on hold during the election season, and the fiscal cliff's potential GDP impact of 4%-5% has businesses hunkering down.

"Companies out there right now are only spending what they need to spend," said Emerson Electric (EMR) CEO David Farr in an earnings call this month. "The uncertainty of what is going to go on relative to U.S. fiscal policy is a big issue."
The global economic slowdown and the possibility of an implosion in Europe are also weighing on companies. And they previously have cited regulations and laws like ObamaCare as obstacles.
Now comes the fiscal cliff, which was scarcely mentioned by firms last quarter but looks to grow more menacing as the year continues.

Some companies, like Caterpillar (CAT), NetApp (NTAP), and Parker Hannifin (PH), are optimistic that lawmakers will act in time to at least moderate the tax hikes and spending cuts. But other executives expressed caution or alarm, according to conference call transcripts from Seeking Alpha.
Richard Heckmann, CEO of Heckmann (HEK), was defiant earlier this month when he said his oilfield services firm is slashing capital expenditures for the second half of the year.
"I don't know a CEO out there that isn't telling you that they're getting very careful about what happens in the second half...
"And if (lawmakers) want to drive off the cliff, let them. But they're just not going to take us with them."
UPS (UPS) CEO D. Scott Davis pointed last month to weak retail sales and manufacturing activity as evidence the fiscal cliff is dragging on the economy.
He added that forecasts for second-half economic growth are too optimistic and will likely be closer to 1%.
Companies aren't just pulling back to minimize potential risks. They're also doing it because their customers are staying on the sidelines to see what happens.
Eaton (ETN), a maker of industrial power management systems, is hearing concerns from customers in different markets.

"In our talking with dealers and key fleets, they're looking at the fiscal cliff at year-end and they're saying, 'I'll wait and I want to see how that's going to sort out,'" said Eaton CEO Alexander Cutler last month.
He added later, "It's not hard for someone to take six months off and then start up again."
Defense contractors have warned about potential layoffs if the Pentagon budget is slashed further, and companies that provide consulting services to the government are keeping new hiring in check.
Booz Allen Hamilton (BAH) said "virtually all" its clients are telling it to hold back. So the firm is being conservative about hiring until work is assured.
Companies as disparate as retailer Target (TGT) and hard disk maker Seagate (STX) said they will take a conservative approach to inventories, due in part to the fiscal cliff.

But others see opportunities as the cliff approaches. Real estate investment trust Kimco Realty (KIM) noted that ordinary dividends from REITs won't be affected by the tax hikes. It is also ready to buy property from owners worried about an increase in the capital gains tax.

"There are sellers who are very worried where tax rates will be next year," said Kimco Chairman Milton Cooper. "And they feel this is the last shot that they have at the lower capital gains."Corporations are scaling back investment, hiring and inventories ahead of steep year-end tax hikes and spending cuts, the most concrete sign to date that uncertainty over the so-called fiscal cliff is already hurting the anemic economy.The automatic, draconian provisions were meant to prod lawmakers to reach their own deficit-cutting deal. ETFs gyrated wildly in the third quarter as the market experienced its worst quarter since the 2008 financial crisis. Whether the roller coaster continues in the fourth quarter depends on the European credit crisis and third-quarter earnings results.

The S&P 500 swung 2% or more in either direction more than half the time. C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL), tracking the so-called fear gauge, rocketed an eye-popping 173% in the July-to-September period. It outperformed all nonleveraged exchange traded products.

SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) slumped 14.3%, SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) 12.0% and PowerShares QQQ (QQQ) 8.0%. If the market does a repeat of 2008, swapping Greece for Bear Stearns, CVOL is very likely to shoot higher still. But the bulls believe comparisons to the 2008 swoon are overblown.

"The economy is growing, albeit very slowly, at a 1.5% GDP growth rate, and earnings are increasing, not declining, as they were in 2008," said Daniel Genter, CEO and CIO of Los Angeles-based RNC Genter Capital Management.

The S&P 500 has shown strong support at 1120 (or $112 for SPY), a level in which it trades close to 12 times 2011 projected per-share earnings of $94, Genter said. That's seen as giving it upside potential because it has typically traded at a higher price/earnings multiple.

"This market has consistently wanted to trade at approximately 14 times forward earnings and has shown significant support during any period in which it has pulled back to anything near 12 times earnings," Genter said.

The bottom-up stock pickers believe many high-quality companies with strong balance sheets have been unduly punished because of investor fear. And they figure the doomsday scenario has already been priced into the market.
"People are focused on the negatives, which is typical of a bottom," said Doug Kreps, a managing director at Fort Pitt Capital Group with more than $1 billion in assets under management.
He believes the S&P won't fall much lower than 1100, or $110 a share for SPY. He projects the S&P will rise to 1300, or $130 a share for SPY, by year's end.
The Bear Case
The bears contend there's too much uncertainty to buy the dip in the near term.

"Right now the European Central Bank, high unemployment and the escalating U.S. government debt is center stage in the focus of financial markets," said Stephen Hammers, portfolio manager of Compass EMP Funds. "Any relief rally would be short-term in nature because markets need to see improving economic fundamentals for a longer-term uptrend to follow. Right now we are not getting that .

"(Federal Reserve Chairman) Ben Bernanke said the jobs market in the U.S. is now a national crisis, and the housing market has yet to recover any of the losses it sustained from the financial crisis of 2008," Hammers added.
His fund is short stock futures and commodities and long on bonds.

David James, co-portfolio manager of James Balanced: Golden Rainbow Fund , has been buying U.S. Treasuries on the expectation that the market will fall further, although he says it may not fall as low as the 2009 bottom.
"The economy, regardless of whether we go through an official recession, will be subpar at best," James said. "In this environment high-quality bonds excel."

Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index ETF  (ZROZ) ranked among the top five nonleveraged ETFs in Q3, vaulting a monumental 58%. PowerShares DB U.S. Dollar Index Bullish (UUP), up 4% for the quarter, rallied as investors flocked to safety in the face of the European debt crisis.

"The U.S. dollar will remain king for some time," James said. "A strengthening dollar will crimp exports. Considering that exports make up over 40% of the S&P 500's sales, this should not be discounted, nor its impact on earnings."

The Federal Reserve's third round of quantitative easing will certainly ignite inflation, sending gold and silver prices higher, say ETF investing advisers. They overwhelmingly favored bullion and miner ETFs when asked last week for their best commodity investing idea for the fourth quarter.  Brett Manning, market analyst at Briefing.com in Chicago: SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) is poised to outperform…

A disparate mix of exchange traded funds rose to the top of the leader board in November as the stock market took ETF investors on a wild roller-coaster ride. And just like at amusement parks, investors got off the same place they got on.

ETF funds tracking volatility, oil and homebuilders outperformed all nonleveraged ETFs. Meanwhile, India, cocoa, and natural gas sold off the most. Volatility-tracking ETFs ran up as the S&P 500 fell for two weeks straight and then rallied 7.5% the last three days of the month. SPDR S&P 500 ETF  (SPY) ended November nearly flat, up 0.37%.
A joint effort by six central banks to save European banks eased fears of a global credit crunch. The move buys time but doesn't solve the European financial sector's problems, said market experts.

"While liquidity injections into troubled banks help reduce the odds of a global credit crunch and are therefore a big short-term equity positive, this action only addresses a symptom of the crisis, not the root cause, which is a lack of confidence in European sovereign debt," Alec Young, global equity strategist at S&P Capital IQ, wrote. "However, it's welcome and should allow for a better tone through year-end."
IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking foreign developed markets, ended November down 2.2%. IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) fell 1.9%.
Where To Invest Now?
Investors should avoid Europe, European bonds and financials, including U.S. ones, Birinyi Associates recommends its clients.

"In the last eight bull markets, 44% of the gain in banks has occurred in the first two months of the rally, and thereafter the names have underperformed," Birinyi said in its December newsletter. "And, as shown last month, in the 1974 and 1998 bull markets they actually lost money after that initial surge."
Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) lost 5.1% for the month. Birinyi also recommends avoiding commodities, gold, energy and basic materials such as chemicals, paper and steel.
"Given that we don't have a clear picture from one day to the next, we have been under-emphasizing these stocks," Birinyi stated.
Birinyi says investors should invest in individual stocks on a case-by-case basis instead.
Here's how ETFs tracking those areas fared in November:
PowerShares DB Commodity Index Tracking Fund (DBC), -0.43%
SPDR Gold Trust (GLD), +1.61%
Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE), +1.7%
Materials Select Sector SPDR (XLB), +0.2%

The best areas of the stock market to invest today are large-cap dividend payers, said Richard Saperstein, managing director of Treasury Partners in New York, a division of Hightower Advisors, with $7 billion in assets under management.

"Currently the S&P's yield is 2.2%, which is in excess of 10-year Treasuries, which has rarely occurred," Saperstein said. "If there's a resolution to Europe, we could see reallocation to stocks from bonds, given the paltry yields in the bond market today."

He believes if there are continued signs of growth in the U.S. and a resolution in Europe, U.S. interest could rise in six to 18 months, which would drive prices down. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

Saperstein also recommends avoiding Europe. The European Central Bank could print money to buy bonds to shore up the indebted countries. But it would require them to enact austerity measures, which would hamper economic growth, he says.
"Given the austerity measures required by the countries to balance their budgets, we can safely say there will be little or no growth out of the euro zone," Saperstein said.

Greece led a global sell-off in May in the face of the eurozone debt crisis and doubts over China's growth.
Performance for the month was in stark contrast to April, when ETFs tracking Vietnam, natural gas and home construction were up 9% to 5%.
In May, Global X FTSE Greece 20 ETF (GREK) — the only ETF tracking the beleaguered country — cratered 33% for the month.

By contrast, iShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA) — tracking developed foreign markets — declined 11%. IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) also sank 11%. Both erased all of their gains this year plus some and are approaching 52-week lows.

Investors are looking toward Greece's June 17 election to clarify whether the country will remain in the eurozone. A Greek departure from the euro is widely seen as stressing the European monetary system.
A marked worsening of the eurozone recession would increase the chances of a hard landing in China. A hard landing in China would directly and indirectly undermine U.S. exports.

"A pullback by American consumers that stalls the U.S. economy would promote distress in Europe, China and just about everywhere else," wrote David Levy, economist and chairman of the Jerome Levy Forecasting Center. "And a chaotic breakdown in Europe would trigger a global decline that could be worse than the 2008-2009 debacle."
Here's an overview of the other biggest losers of the month:
Downside To Natgas

IPath Dow Jones-UBS Natural Gas Total Return Sub-Index ETN (GAZ) imploded 28% to nearly a new low, while natgas futures ticked up 4%. It has been trading like a closed-end fund, gyrating on supply and demand independent of its NAV, after Barclays Bank stopped issuing new shares in August 2009.
Barclays warned traders to stay away from it after it traded as high as 50% above its indicative value on May 17.

"Due to likely continued fluctuations in this premium, Barclays believes that the ETNs are currently not suitable for most investors and will not track the price of the underlying natural gas futures index in a consistent manner," Barclays said in a statement.
The ETN trades an average 432,000 shares a day, less than half the level of seven weeks ago.

Market Vectors Solar Energy ETF (KWT) dropped 23%. The government-subsidy dependent industry has been spiraling down the past 15 months. Europe's financial crisis forced governments to cut subsidies. Panels still aren't cheap enough to compete with energy produced by fossil fuels.
First Trust ISE Global Platinum Index (PLTM) melted 22% in May.

"Platinum is tied to the overall commodity trade as well as economic growth outlook," says Terry Sacka, chief strategist at Cornerstone Asset Metals in Jupiter, Fla. "Both have looked bleak recently due to European uncertainty and the global financial deflation trade resurging."
He recommends buying the precious metal if the government prints more money in June. If not, he expects for it to resume falling.
Biggest ETF Winners
Volatility ETFs, which tend to move opposite the market, rose to the top of the winner's list in May.
C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL) shot up 34%. ProShares VIX Short-Term Futures ETF (VIXY) vaulted 22%.
Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index ETF (ZROZ) rallied 15% on safe-haven buying. Benchmark 10-year Treasury bond yields fell to a 60-year low of 1.62%.
U.S. Market Review, Outlook
SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) and PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the 100 largest nonfinancial Nasdaq stocks, ended the month down 6% to 7%.
Some market watchers recommend buying on weakness, noting corporate earnings are at all-time highs.
With nearly all of the S&P 500 companies having reported first-quarter results, earnings are up 8% year over year. About two in three companies beat forecasts.
So compared with safe-haven Treasuries, whose yields fail to even match inflation, equities look more attractive.

"The combination of the rising equity risk premium, falling stock prices, improving corporate earnings and lower Treasury yields means that stocks have become quite cheap relative to bonds," wrote Bob Doll, chief equity strategist and manager of large-cap funds at Blackrock.

"Assuming that the world is not headed for a renewed deflationary spiral," Doll added, "there is little doubt in our view that stocks are poised to provide superior long-term returns over bonds given their current levels."
Birinyi's Ideas
The market is in the third leg of a four-part bull market spanning five years, Birinyi Associates told clients in its June newsletter.
Its analysts recommend buying SPY, DIA as well as Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR (XLP) and Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR (XLY).

"Given China, we would basically avoid material stocks including energy," Birinyi wrote. "The financials will see further pressure, not only because of JPMorgan Chase (JPM), but also continued negative response to Facebook (FB); health care has long been out of favor, so large portions of the S&P can virtually be eliminated."

Major exchange traded funds rebounded from oversold levels after selling off in the morning on a U.S. factory orders report that showed a surprise drop.

Orders for goods produced in U.S. factories dropped 0.6% in April, the Commerce Department said Monday. Economists had expected a rise of 0.1%. March orders were revised to show an even bigger decline.

In late afternoon trading, the SPDR S&P 500  (SPY) fell 3 cents to 128.13, still below its 200-day moving average after closing below that key level on Friday. It's tumbled 10% from its multi-year peak in April, signaling a technical correction.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) fell 0.2%.
PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the largest-100 non-financial stocks on the Nasdaq, added 0.2%.

Foreign markets bounced back from oversold levels as bargain hunters supported prices. iShares MSCI EAFE Index  (EFA), tracking developed foreign markets, added 0.8%. iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index  (EEM) rose 0.4%.
Some asset financial gurus say stocks have fallen to bargain prices that investors should embrace.

"The S&P 500 is trading at approximately 13 times forward earnings, which is more than 20% cheaper than October 2007 levels," Ethan Anderson, chief investment strategist at Rehmann in Grand Rapids, Minn., told clients in a note. "Second, corporate balance sheets, especially those of financial institutions, are cash heavy due to lessons learned in 2008."

Emerging markets are even cheaper, trading at nine times forward earnings estimates. But low valuations in the absence of positive growth catalysts could be a value trap, says Alec Young, global equity strategist at S&P Capital IQ.

"They reflect the very real possibility of continued downside surprises to U.S., European and BRIC growth rates as well as the potential for a major negative credit event in Europe as its crisis continues to spiral out of control," Young said in a client note Monday. "Amidst this deteriorating macro-economic backdrop, consensus earnings per share revisions have recently been negative for Europe, Canada, Australia, China, India and Brazil, suggesting to us that greater confidence in future growth is needed to spark lasting price-to-earnings expansion."

He warned, however, any positive news out of Europe could spark a short-covering rally in which short sellers have to buy back stocks to close out their positions, thereby driving up prices. And a counter-trend rally would be short-lived.
Biggest Gainers

iPath U.S. Treasury Long Bond Bull ETN  (DLBL) surged 4.11%, outpacing the non-leveraged ETF universe. The note tracks increases and decreases in the yield of long-dated U.S. Treasury bonds. The 10-year bond yield rose 0.055% to 1.524% as prices eased from overbought levels. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Investors flocked to Treasuries as a safe haven but this may prove dangerous once rock-bottom interest rates bounce back from record lows, says Peter Schiff, CEO of Euro Pacific Capital.

"There is no way to justify record low-interest rates in this country given our atrocious fiscal position," Schiff wrote. "I believe interest rates here should approach levels comparable to the more indebted European countries.
"Once it becomes obvious just how many dollars the Fed is prepared to print to stave off recession, people running into treasuries today will likely suffer buyer's remorse."

Asian and European bourses suffered two days of losses that, when added together, reflect some serious red ink.South Korea's Kospi index fell 2.2%, the biggest loss Friday among the major Asian markets. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.4% while Australia's All Ordinaries lost 1% and Taiwan's weighted index slipped 0.8%.Most of these losses seem muted vs. the 2%-2.2% declines logged Thursday by the U.S. indexes. Only South Korea suffered a matching blow.But a closer look shows that Asia had already taken some hits Thursday, presaging the U.S. nose dive.It may be more useful to look at the combined two-day losses for those markets.South Korea's Kospi fell 3%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng ceded 2.7%, Australia's All Ordinaries lost 2% and Taiwan's weighted dropped 1.5%.Western Europe, meanwhile, took most of its losses Friday, although those markets also lost ground Thursday.The German DAX-30-share index fell 0.8% Thursday and 1.3% Friday. France's CAC-40 logged declines of 0.4% Thursday and 0.8% Friday.The U.K.'s FTSE 100 fell 1% Thursday and 1% Friday.So how does this rocky action affect the IBD Daily World Map, which compares 16 foreign exchange traded funds and two major U.S. stock indexes?Year to date, one sees little reason for Americans to invest abroad. The Nasdaq leads the 18 markets on the Map with an 11% return.IShares MSCI Mexico ETF (EWW) places second with a 7.3% return and the S&P 500 shows third with a rise of 6.2%.The top five are rounded out with iShares MSCI South Africa ETF (EZA), up 3.3%, and iPath India ETN (INP), up 3.1%. IShares MSCI Germany ETF (EWG) holds the No. 10 slot on a year-to-date basis (up 0.1%).IShares MSCI U.K. ETF (EWU) stands in 12th place (off 0.9%) and iShares MSCI France ETF (EWQ) (off 3.8%) is in 14th place.IShares MSCI Brazil ETF (EWZ) is firmly entrenched in the Daily World Map's basement, with an 11.6% decline.Even that poor showing would look modest if Spain, one of the current crisis countries of the EU, were included. IShares MSCI Spain ETF (EWP) shows a steep 20.9% drop.

Performance by mutual funds that invest in India has been as beautiful as the Taj Mahal this year.
Funds focused on companies in the subcontinent lead all regional fund categories tracked by Morningstar Inc.
The 11 India funds tracked by Morningstar averaged an 8.84% gain, going into Thursday. That's more than double the 3.49% gain by Pacific/Asia ex-Japan funds. And it noses past the S&P 500's 8.71%.
But don't pile into India stock funds based just on that. India funds have been volatile this year, and are likely to remain so.
IPath MCSI India ETN (INP), a proxy for the Indian stock market, gained 21.13% in the first quarter. But INP plunged 8.68% in Q2.
Now, over the past one month, INP is soaring again, up 2.35%. The S&P 500 has tumbled 3.26%.

India investments face some head winds, says Alec Young, analyst for S&P Capital IQ. They include a big government budget deficit, a big trade deficit and slowing but still-high inflation of about 7%.
Also, the rupee has lost about 26% of its value vs. the dollar in the past 12 months. And investors are tilting away from riskier markets globally while they trim exposure to weak eurozone markets.
Further, a pro-regulatory government makes it hard to start or expand businesses, says Anup Maheshwari, lead adviser of $4 million BlackRock India Investor Fund .
Most of those challenges are to blame for the India market's overall downtrend since the end of 2010, says Christopher Darling, manager of $349 million Eaton Vance Greater India .
Factors Favoring India

Despite those problems, Darling cites reasons he still likes his market, including the sharp fall in oil's price, strong domestic consumption and growing strength in engineering and the making of cars and drugs.
Also, India's need for infrastructure improvements should fuel the domestic construction industry.
And its relatively modest reliance on exports insulates India from a slowdown in growth among consumer nations.
Going forward, Darling likes financial services and banking in particular. The slowdown in GDP growth has eased inflationary pressure, boosting the odds of an interest-rate cut.
Maheshwari also likes several banks, including HDFC, citing its average of 30% year-over-year quarterly earnings growth for 55 quarters. He sees 25% quarterly growth for the next two years.
And he likes ICICI Bank, (IBN) which he says has an attractive valuation and improving fundamentals.
Darling's drugmaker prognosis is rosy due to a large number of medicines going off-patent in the U.S.
Maheshwari says Dr. Reddy Laboratories (RDY) is strong domestically and has a lot of U.S. sales. There is an ADR version of Dr. Reddy.
S&P Capital IQ likes Sun Pharmaceutical, a holding of $606 million Matthews India , citing what Capital IQ calls an above-average quality ranking, due to consistent earnings and dividend growth.

Domestic consumption should keep driving Indian automakers, Darling says. He owns Tata Motors, (TTM)) which has an ADR. Sales grew 29%, 35% and 36% the past three years. The euphoria that shot foreign markets higher after Spain's bank bailout quickly fizzled Monday morning as terms of the loans came to light. Investors rushed back into safe-haven U.S. Treasuries as the rescue plan raised concerns about whether it's large enough and how it would ever be repaid.

Under the plan, Spain — Europe's fourth-largest economy — will borrow up to 100 billion euros ($125 billion) to shore up its battered banks, which are suffering from a massive housing bust. The European Union and International Monetary Fund now have committed around 500 billion euros to bailout Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain.

"With a much larger economy than the other fund-seeking EU members, a Spanish bailout could not only severely test the EU's various funding mechanisms, but could lead to further speculation predicting the demise of the European Currency Union," Matt Freund, senior vice president of investment portfolio management of USAA Investments, wrote.

The bailout money will be tacked on to Spain's sovereign debt, which likely will lead to more downgrades. Fitch Ratings downgraded two Spanish banks, Banco Santander (STD) and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), by two notches, placing them three levels above junk status. Fitch downgraded Spain to triple B — two notches above junk — last week on the expectation that the country will remain in recession through 2013.

"The delusion that government creates money out of nothing will vanish as the European System of Financial Supervisors (ESFS) and European Stability Mechanism (ESM) weigh the crucial question of who is going to pay for it," Jeff Sica, founder of SICA Wealth Management, wrote in a note. "The ESFS is allegedly funded up to $200 billion. This bailout could deplete that fund almost entirely if in fact those dollars exist. The ESM requires ratification from Germany, which would mean Germany will absorb the majority of losses if Spanish banks fail."
Sica recommends investors buy gold and silver and keep their money in cash.
SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) ticked up 0.25% Monday. IShares Silver Trust (SLV) added 0.07%.

"(Central) Banks can print or borrow all the money they need but gold cannot be printed," said David Morgan of the Morgan Report. Banks are not trusting each other and will accelerate their gold buying, he said.
Market Overview
SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) gapped up 0.9% at the open and then fell the rest of the morning. In afternoon trade, the SPY was down 0.2%.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) fell 0.25%.
PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the largest 100 non-financial stocks on the Nasdaq, slipped 0.24%.
iShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking developed foreign markets, eased 0.18%.
iShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) lost 0.15%.
Both EFA and EEM gapped up about 1% at the open and sold off immediately.
Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index ETF (ZROZ) shot up 0.52% as yields on benchmark 10-year bonds fell four basis points to 1.6%.
Economist David Levy of the Jerome Levy Forecasting Center believes the 10-year Treasury yield will possibly fall below 1% this year and the 30-year yield will dip below 2%.
The risks of a global recession — including the U.S. beginning in 2012 — are real, and global recession over the next two or three years is probable, Levy says.

"Given the intensifying shortage of safe assets, significantly lower yields are possible," he wrote. "The 'contained depression' in the U.S. and Europe continues to thwart the private profit sources, and the relentless pressures caused by excessive balance sheets ceaselessly weigh on the global economy."

Follow Trang Ho on Twitter @TrangHoETFs.The euphoria that shot foreign markets higher after Spain's bank bailout quickly fizzled Monday morning as terms of the loans came to light. Investors rushed back into safe-haven U.S. Treasuries as the rescue plan raised concerns about whether it's large enough and how it would ever be repaid.Under the plan, Spain — Europe's fourth-largest economy — will borrow up to 100 billion euros ($125 billion) to shore up its battered banks, which are suffering from a massive housing bust. The European Union and International Monetary Fund now have committed around 500 billion euros to bailout Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain."With a much larger economy than the other fund-seeking EU members, a Spanish bailout could not only severely test the EU's various funding mechanisms, but could lead to further speculation predicting the demise of the European Currency Union," Matt Freund, senior vice president of investment portfolio management of USAA Investments, wrote.The bailout money will be tacked on to Spain's sovereign debt, which likely will lead to more downgrades. Fitch Ratings downgraded two Spanish banks, Banco Santander (STD) and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), by two notches, placing them three levels above junk status. Fitch downgraded Spain to triple B — two notches above junk — last week on the expectation that the country will remain in recession through 2013."The delusion that government creates money out of nothing will vanish as the European System of Financial Supervisors (ESFS) and European Stability Mechanism (ESM) weigh the crucial question of who is going to pay for it," Jeff Sica, founder of SICA Wealth Management, wrote in a note. "The ESFS is allegedly funded up to $200 billion. This bailout could deplete that fund almost entirely if in fact those dollars exist. The ESM requires ratification from Germany, which would mean Germany will absorb the majority of losses if Spanish banks fail."Sica recommends investors buy gold and silver and keep their money in cash.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) ticked up 0.25% Monday. IShares Silver Trust (SLV) added 0.07%."(Central) Banks can print or borrow all the money they need but gold cannot be printed," said David Morgan of the Morgan Report. Yields on Spain's 10-year bonds reached a new euro-era high of 7.57% on Tuesday. IShares MSCI Spain Index (EWP) plunged 4.66% to a nine-year low. PowerShares DB US Dollar…
Natural gas and Greece ETFs exploded higher while volatility imploded Thursday as the market recovered the prior day's losses.

United States Natural Gas (UNG) — tracking futures contracts — surged 12.4%. First Trust ISE-Revere Natural Gas Index (FCG) — tracking the producers — shot up 2.5%. Natgas has been falling the past four years because advances in fracking technology led to a production glut, while warm weather dampened demand for gas-fired heating. Natgas futures have collapsed 83% from their July 2008 peak to $2.28 per million British thermal units (BTUs).

U.S. natural gas inventories increased by 67 billion cubic feet (BCF) last week, the U.S. Energy Department reported. That was lower than the consensus estimate of 71 to 75 BCF, according to a Platts survey of analysts.

Production is slowing at current prices and rig counts are falling, while demand is surging as electric utilities switch to natgas from coal, said Shawn Hackett, president of Hackett Financial Advisors in Boynton Beach, Fla. In addition, trucks are converting from running on diesel to natgas to take advantage of the low prices, he said.

"My expectation is that the bear market is over and that a bull market will begin starting in the fall," Hackett said. He believes natgas bottomed in April at $1.97 per million BTUs and will consolidate sideways for several months and then break out.
The trend change prompted Waverly Advisors to buy natgas.

"We have been monitoring Natty for a potential trend chance since late March, and do see the tactical/technical support for a potential trend change," said Adam Grimes, chief investment officer at Waverly.

In another surprise move, Global X FTSE Greece 20 ETF (GREK) gapped up 11%. The country's election this weekend could set it on a path to leave the eurozone. The ETF has cratered 46% from its February peak. It's still trading deep below its moving averages so it just looks like a counter-trend rally. The debt-ridden country's unemployment rate rose to a record 22% in the first quarter. Struggling with austerity measures and swelling debt, Greece is in its fifth year of recession.
Volatility ETFs, which tend to move opposite the market, fell the most among nonleveraged ETFs. C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL) fell 4%.
Market Overview
In afternoon trading, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) climbed 0.51%.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) jumped 0.75%.
PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), a basket of the 100 largest nonfinancial stocks on the Nasdaq, shed 0.10%.
IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking developed foreign markets, rose 0.22%.
IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) ticked up 0.11%.
Initial U.S. unemployment claims rose by 6,000 last week to 386,000 vs. 375,000 that economists had expected. Consumer prices fell 0.3% in May from April due to falling gas prices.
In Europe, Spanish 10-year bonds hit a euro-era high of more than 7% Thursday after another debt downgrade from Moody's. Italy's borrowing costs also rose.
Weak economic data and concerns over Europe raised the hopes of investors of further stimulus or quantitative easing from the Federal Reserve, Morningstar reported.
Strategas Research Partners wrote:

"QE1 bought the equity markets a 13.5-month rally. QE2 bought the markets 10 months. The LTRO (long-term refinancing operations) and Operation Twist appear to have bought about 6 months. There's a diminishing return in the 'risk' trade with these types of policy responses.
"But we're likely to keep getting sequels, even if they're worse than the original. China eased last week, and the European Central Bank and Fed talked dovishly (that) nothing is 'off the table.'"

ETF providers unveiled a raft of new foreign ETFs in the past week. Here's an overview:

 IShares MSCI Denmark Capped Investable Market Index Fund (EDEN) holds 31 stocks. Drugmaker Novo Nordisk (NVO) alone takes up more than a fifth of assets. Moller - Maersk (AMKBF), a marine and truck transportation provider, and Carlsberg (CABGY), a beverage maker, are the other names most familiar to U.S. investors. The fund most heavily weights health care, with 35% of assets. Other weightings are industrials at 27%, financials 16%, consumer staples 9% and materials 6%.

The MSCI Denmark index lost 16.9% in the past 12 months. Its average annual return was 16.0%, -0.66% and 10.6% over the past three, five and 10 years, according to MSCI. The EAFE index, the benchmark for foreign developed markets, lost 12.8% in the past year. Its average annual return was 9.8%, -6.3% and 3.1% in the past three, five and 10 years. 

IShares MSCI Finland Capped Investable Market Index Fund (EFNL) holds 42 stocks, with cellphone maker Nokia (NOK) accounting for 17% of assets. EFNL has 28% of its money in industrials, followed by info tech 18%, materials 16%, financials 13% and utilities 8%. The MSCI Finland index's average annual return was -31.5%, -1.5%, -12.6% and -3.6% the past one, three, five and 10 years.

 IShares MSCI Norway Capped Investable Market Index Fund (ENOR) holds 52 stocks led by Statoil (STO), comprising 21% of the fund, Telenor (TELNY) 8% and SeaDrill Limited (SDRL) 7%. Energy accounts for half of the fund. Financials, materials and telecom and industrials account for 9%, 8% and 7% of assets, respectively. The MSCI Norway index returned -7.5%, 18.9%, -4.9% and 10.6% annualized the past one, three, five and 10 years.

"Northern European countries generally have a reputation of being fiscally responsible, so ETFs linked to the performance of Nordic countries such as ENOR, EDEN and EFNL have a fair chance of outperforming other countries during periods of global economic distress," said Simon Maierhofer, co-founder of ETFGuide.com.
All three ETFs charge a 0.53% annual fee. They'll compete with Global X FTSE Nordic Region ETF  (GXF). ENOR will go up against Global X FTSE Norway 30 ETF  (NORW).

 ProShares German Sovereign/Sub-Sovereign ETF (GGOV) holds debt notes issued by the German government, local governments and agencies. It tracks the Markit iBoxx EUR Germany Sovereign & Sub-Sovereign Liquid Index. The average coupon yields 3.52%. It carries a 0.45% expense ratio.
"Obviously it's Germany's AAA rating that makes GGOV attractive to investors," said Maierhofer.
GGOV will compete with PIMCO Germany Bond Index Fund (BUND), PowerShares DB German Bund Futures ETN (BUNL) and PowerShares DB 3x German Bund Futures ETN (BUNT).

 AdvisorShares Accuvest Global Opportunities ETF (ACCU) is an ETF of ETFs actively managed by Accuvest Global Advisors. The country-rotation strategy involves ranking 29 country ETFs on 40 variables each month, and buying the top five or six highest-ranked ones. Some of the factors considered are economic growth, earnings, price action, volatility and valuations. No more than 25% of fund assets can be put into an ETF.
ACCU aims to beat the MSCI All Country World Index. It currently holds:
1. iShares MSCI Thailand Index Fund  (THD), 21% of assets.
2. iShares S&P 500 Index  (IVV), 20%.
3. iShares MSCI Brazil Index  (EWZ), 16%.
4. iShares MSCI South Africa Index  (EZA), 15% .
5. ishares MSCI Russia Capped Index Fund  (ERUS), 14%.
6. iShares FTSE/Xinhua China 25 Index  (FXI), 14%.
It charges a rather expensive 1.78% annual management fee.

Stocks stayed on pace to score solid gains in late-afternoon action Monday, recovering somewhat from their worst weekly declines so far in 2012. The Nasdaq was up 2%, while the S&P 500 added 1.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.8%. Volume was down across the board from Friday's levels, which were boosted by options expirations. Last week, the Nasdaq…
Rock-bottom interest rates have investors searching high and low for income alternatives to CDs, money market funds and Treasuries.
Decent total return would be nice too.
Funds that invest in energy transportation and storage master limited partnerships (MLPs) in general are providing just that.

Holdings of the Cushing 30 MLP Index averaged a 6.7% yield over the 12 months ended Dec. 31, according to Cushing MLP Asset Management, which runs funds that invest in energy MLPs. Average yield for 10-year Treasuries was 2% and 4.6% for BBB rated bonds. Utilities yielded 4% and REITs 3.7%.
And total return by the Alerian MLP Index, which tracks 50 names, topped the S&P 500 the past 12 calendar years, according to research firm U.S. Capital Advisors.

Due to tax rules, MLPs in this space run facilities that transport or store natural gas and oil in the U.S. They are not engaged in exploration, production or retail resale. They are called midstream MLPs.
"Their upside is that they generate high free cash flow to investors," said Daniel Spears, a manager of Cushing's $203 million MLP Premier Fund and $313 million MLP Total Return (SRV).
Know Your Impact
You can find MLPs in open- and closed-end mutual funds, ETFs and ETNs.
Before leaping in, individual investors should understand how those differences would affect their tax bills and total returns.
For example, among the various types of funds that invest in these MLPs, only ETNs are not taxed at the corporate level, at a 35% rate.
But ETN distributions often consist of interest income, which is taxed at ordinary income rates.
ETN distributions are higher than the usual 15% rate on dividends paid by funds and ETFs.
And some funds' distributions consist of return of capital.

"As you decide what type of fund you want to invest in, make sure you understand what type of distributions it pays," said Brian Watson, director of research for SteelPath Advisors, which runs three open-end funds.

Distributions directly from an MLP trigger K-1 schedules at tax time. Businesses often send K-1s late in the tax season, forcing investors to file for an extension. And K-1s can have more extra state filing requirements.
Funds report payouts on 1099s.
Another key difference is that ETNs and ETFs have passive management, investing in indexes.
Closed-end funds can be actively run, and many use leverage. That heightens their volatility.
Open-end funds are typically actively run, without leverage.

Cushing's Spears is bullish for at least 2012 because U.S. energy production and infrastructure buildout are rising. By 2035 the U.S. will build an additional $250 billion in facilities, according to the Interstate Natural Gas Association of America. And revenue for midstream MLPs is hurt little if any when prices for gas and oil decline.

SteelPath's Watson is also constructive. "Last year's returns were good, not great. Valuations are still reasonable, about where they were at the start of 2011. Industrywide, I see 2012 total return around 10%, which is not frothy by any means."Rock-bottom interest rates have investors searching high and low for income alternatives to CDs, money market funds and Treasuries.Decent total return would be nice too.Funds that invest in energy transportation and storage master limited partnerships (MLPs) in general are providing just that.Holdings of the Cushing 30 MLP Index averaged a 6.7% yield over the 12 months ended Dec. 31, according to Cushing MLP Asset Management, which runs funds that invest in energy MLPs.
