2011 showed ETF investors how the stock market could turn viciously in either direction every other day. We asked several ETF experts and asset managers for ideas on how to fight back should the bears maul the bulls in 2012.
 Simon Maierhofer, founder of ETF Profit Strategy Newsletter in San Diego, Calif.

IShares Barclays 1-3 Year Treasury Bond (SHY): I expect 2012 to be a very dangerous, possibly even devastating, year for stocks. It's better to be safe than sorry, hence my two-prong philosophy for 2012: 1) Preserve your capital. There are two types of losses an investor can suffer: a loss of opportunity or a loss of capital. There will always be another opportunity, but you need to preserve your capital to be able to take advantage of it. 2) Don't be shy about taking profits.

Key resistance and the likely range for a historic market top for the S&P 500 in 2011 was at 1,369-1,382, while key support was at 1,088. I think the bounce off support at 1,088 was a countertrend rally and expect the bear market will continue in 2012. The strategy is to sell into rallies.

Only a close above an important descending trend line (at 1,330 in January 2012) or the launch of more quantitative easing in the U.S. or something like QE in Europe would temporarily suspend my bearish outlook. I expect the S&P to drop below the October low at 1,074 and possibly much lower in 2012.

Conservative investors should stay out of the market or use tight stop-loss orders (right beneath important support). Cash is king in a deflationary environment, and one of the safest places to be in 2012 will be short-term U.S. Treasuries like SHY.
 Vinny Catalano, president of Blue Marble Capital Management in New York.

ProShares Short Russell 2000 (RWM): As someone who believes stocks are in the early stages of a bear market, RWM will rise should the market decline as I expect it will. (Inverse ETFs go up when stocks go down.)

Should stocks rise, then an inverse ETF like RWM will fall — and that is the primary risk for this idea. While there are other inverse ETFs that will rise if the market goes down, I prefer RWM because it represents small-sized companies, which are fairly overvalued.

Expectations of high earnings growth have pushed the price of small stocks well above where the larger stocks in the overall market are. Moreover, small stocks are more volatile and therefore will decline at a much more rapid rate than larger stocks will.

The one argument against using an inverse of small-cap stocks is that they are less exposed to the global problems buffeting the world markets. But this assumes that the problems in the world won't eventually impact all issues, and this includes small companies in the U.S.

On its own, RWM is not a low-risk investment and investors should not put all their eggs in this one basket. But as hedge against other positions and in a prudent proportion to one's overall portfolio, RWM is an appropriate pick for a stock market that has risk written all over it.
 John Nyaradi, publisher of Wall Street Sector Selector in Bend, Ore.

IPath S&P 500 VIX Short Term Futures ETN (VXX) and VelocityShares Daily Inverse VIX Short Term ETN (XIV): Looking ahead to 2012, one prediction that most analysts seem to agree on is that volatility in global markets will continue. Volatility can make for tough investing conditions but also offers potential opportunity if one invests in volatility itself.

Therefore, two of my favorite ETNs for 2012 will likely be those that track long and short directional moves in the VIX, the CBOE Volatility Index. The VIX, also known as the "fear indicator," uses the implied volatility of S&P 500 index options and is an index of the market's forward looking view of volatility for the next 30 days.
Observers say that when the VIX is declining, stock prices are likely to trend higher, while when VIX is in an uptrend, lower stock prices could be ahead.

For rising VIX environments, the VXX is a popular, liquid and widely traded ETN designed to rise in price as the VIX rises. For declining volatility environments, XIV is designed to rise in price as the VIX declines.

A couple of words of caution are in order. While these ETNs are designed to track the VIX, they do not precisely replicate its action, and so your gains/losses could vary widely from that of the index. Also, you must approach these ETNs with a professional plan because volatility is, well, volatile. I'm quite sure that I will find myself on both sides of the VIX during an unpredictable New Year.
 Alan Rosenfield, managing director of Harmony Asset Management in Scottsdale, Ariz.
ProShares Short MSCI Emerging Markets ETF (EUM): This fund is an inverse (nonleveraged) of 21 emerging markets. The largest country holdings are China, Korea, Brazil, Taiwan, South Africa and India.

A slowdown in the European Union and in China will result in slower growth in many emerging countries. Many are struggling already with higher inflation and lower growth. Money is leaving China now and this could accelerate. Countries trying to spend their way out of their debt problems will lead to further economic weakness, benefiting EUM.

The risk to this strategy is if worldwide economies actually start to grow, the fund will obviously do poorly. The greater risk is if economies continue to just stumble along, neither getting much stronger or weaker. Then this fund, because it is designed to be a short-term vehicle, will go down in value even if markets are flat.

This article is the fifth in a series on the outlook for ETFs in 2012.2011 showed ETF investors how the stock market could turn viciously in either direction every other day. We asked several ETF experts and asset managers for ideas on how to fight back should the bears maul the bulls in 2012. Simon Maierhofer, founder of ETF Profit Strategy Newsletter in San Diego, Calif.IShares Barclays 1-3 Year Treasury Bond (SHY): I expect 2012 to be a very dangerous, possibly even devastating, year for stocks. It's better to be safe than sorry, hence my two-prong philosophy for 2012: 1) Preserve your capital. There are two types of losses an investor can suffer: a loss of opportunity or a loss of capital. There will always be another opportunity, but you need to preserve your capital to be able to take advantage of it. 2) Don't be shy about taking profits.Key resistance and the likely range for a historic market top for the S&P 500 in 2011 was at 1,369-1,382, while key support was at 1,088. I think the bounce off support at 1,088 was a countertrend rally and expect the bear market will continue in 2012. The strategy is to sell into rallies.Only a close above an important descending trend line (at 1,330 in January 2012) or the launch of more quantitative easing in the U.S. or something like QE in Europe would temporarily suspend my bearish outlook. I expect the S&P to drop below the October low at 1,074 and possibly much lower in 2012.Conservative investors should stay out of the market or use tight stop-loss orders (right beneath important support). Cash is king in a deflationary environment, and one of the safest places to be in 2012 will be short-term U.S. Treasuries like SHY. Vinny Catalano, president of Blue Marble Capital Management in New York. (Inverse ETFs go up when stocks go down.)Should stocks rise, then an inverse ETF like RWM will fall — and that is the primary risk for this idea. Countries, like stocks, are either leaders or laggards. Results from the first quarter shed light on where the best opportunities have appeared among the Daily World Map's 18 markets.First, let's bear in mind the broad picture: A disaster in Europe has been narrowly averted, for the moment. With a recession in Europe, slowing growth in China and an unreliable rebound in the U.S., many are wondering where the world's growth engine will be found.The answer, perhaps, may lie in not one but dozens of central banks around the world. After a year of fighting inflation with higher interest rates, restricting credit and other tightening moves, the trend now is for easier policies to avoid a hard landing.Now rates are falling, liquidity-pumping is rising and loans are easier to find. The easy money has boosted foreign indexes and exchange traded funds.For instance, iPath India ETN (INP) shows an 21.1% quarterly gain, putting it in a tie for best performer on the Daily World Map. That's in stark contrast to its 12-month move, which shows a 24% loss (the Map's third-worst by that gauge).India shares the top spot with iShares MSCI Germany ETF (EWG). Its big advance may be puzzling to those transfixed by the grim headlines we see from Europe.The specter of higher taxes and budget cuts hangs over Germany, as it does over most of Europe. The Continent already has slipped back into recession.So where does the Germany ETF's strength come from? It could be the European Central Bank's recent move to easier monetary policy, including a sort of back-door to quantitative easing. (It had promised for years that it would not conduct such a move).Also remember that the Germany ETF had taken a drubbing during last year's Greek crisis. That damage can still be seen when looking at its 12-month return, which shows an 11% loss. By that gauge, it ranks 10th out of the Daily World Map's 18 markets.The No. 3 performer on the Daily World Map also is the  Nasdaq, with an 18.7% return. Maybe you don't really have to go too far to find big winners.Are you thinking that the Nasdaq's results may be lifted by some well-performing ADRs such as NetEase (NTES) and MercadoLibre (MELI)? Maybe, but a scan of Nasdaq's market leaders shows few foreign companies. It's been years since Chinese ADRs held seven of the IBD 50's top 10 slots. Those were the days.Rounding out the Map's top five you'll find iShares MSCI Mexico (EWW) (up 16.3%) and Market Vectors TR Russia (RSX) (up 15.9%).A surprise may be found in the Daily World Map's basement, where you'll find iShares FTSE China 25 (FXI) ETF, with a quarterly climb of just 5.1%.China's growth is the Map's biggest, and the central bank has been easing since October after a full year of credit-tightening measures.So why is China lagging so badly? Growth is probably slowing from last year's 9.2% pace. Austerity budgets in Europe are anathema to export-driven economies, and China's is the biggest.Perhaps, too, fund managers are avoiding Chinese companies, worried that they simply can't trust the numbers.Too many Chinese companies lied about customers, sales and cash on hand. Evidence appeared recently that local governments encouraged this behavior.

In a year of slow U.S. economic growth, investors sought out low volatility, defensive sectors whose steady profits aren't dependent on economic growth. What's more, low…

He points to the collapse in commodities, underperformance in the faster-growing emerging markets and weakness in discretionary stocks juxtaposed with a possible bottoming…

Most ETFs fulfill the promise of low cost and all-day trade. But some are so rife with flaws, they should be handled with great care or avoided altogether. We asked several ETF strategists to tell us which they think are the worst ETFs and why.
 Ron Rowland, founder, All Star Investor and Capital Cities Asset Management, Austin, Texas.

Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP): Ever since Congress created the Investment Company Act of 1940, the investing public has come to associate mutual funds, and now ETFs, as investment vehicles that are "pass-through" structures from an income tax standpoint. In other words, investors believe that funds themselves do not incur or pay any taxes. Any and all tax obligations are "passed through" to the shareholders. AMLP changed that.

There are more than 1,100 ETFs and ETNs listed for trading in the U.S. today. Of those, AMLP is the only one structured as a C-corporation. Because it is the first of its kind, investors are not aware of the outrageous expenses that come with this structure.
As a C-corp, it has to pay 35% federal income tax on all capital gains (price appreciation) as well as various state tax liabilities. This burden is of course ultimately borne by the shareholders.

Since AMLP does not know who or how many shareholders it will have when its tax bill becomes due, it must accrue this on a daily basis. AMLP accomplishes this by reducing the daily price change by 37.5%, leaving shareholders with the other 62.5%.

According to data from AMLP's website, since its launch on Aug. 25, 2010, through the end of 2010, AMLP shareholders only received 65% of the total return generated by the underlying benchmark index (8.7% vs. 13.5%). That is the equivalent of a 35% expense ratio.

The 35% entity-level tax obligation is before and in addition to the shareholder's tax obligations. If you bought AMLP in a taxable account when it was launched and sold on Dec. 31, you now owe taxes on your 8.7% return. Depending on your tax rate, this might reduce your return by another 20% to 40% of the remainder. It's essentially the compounding of taxes, or double taxation.

AMLP likes to counter this argument, saying that their distributions are tax-deferred. However, tax-deferred is not the same as tax-free, and having the fund pay 35% corporate taxes seems to defeat the whole purpose. MLPs are one of the most tax-efficient vehicles available to investors. However, AMLP is the least tax-efficient ETF that I'm aware of.
I don't claim to be a tax specialist, but no one has indicated that my analysis is incorrect. Investors should consult their own tax adviser about their particular situation.
 Michael Johnston, senior ETF analyst, ETF Database, Chicago.

RBS U.S. Large Cap Trendpilot ETN (TRND): Trend following has become a very popular investment strategy, so a trend-following exchange traded product seems like it might be a big hit. The RBS U.S. Large Cap Trendpilot ETN is a relatively simple product. When the S&P 500 is above its 200-day moving average, investors get exposure to equities. When the S&P 500 dips below its 200-day, exposure is shifted to low-risk Treasuries.

But TRND is full of faults, and just doesn't make much sense for investors. For starters, the fees charged by this product are just plain ridiculous. When the strategy is invested in the S&P 500, expenses accrue at an annual rate of 1.0%. That's almost 17 times the fees charged by the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO). When invested in Treasuries, expenses accrue at 0.50%, or 41 basis points more than PIMCO 1-3 Year U.S. Treasury Index ETF (TUZ). There's nothing proprietary or complex about the underlying strategy, so going the do-it-yourself route could save you quite a bit in fees.

Then there's the potential "strategy lag" that results from TRND's methodology. Most investors implementing a trend-following strategy shift exposure as soon as a specified price point (such as the 200-day moving average) is crossed. But TRND implements a bastardized version of trend following; in order to shift into equity exposure, the S&P 500 must be above its moving average for five consecutive trading days. Conversely, it takes five straight days below to get into cash. That puts TRND behind the trend-following curve, potentially leaving some money on the table.
To top it off, TRND is a debt security issued by a financial institution that not long ago needed a $75 billion bailout just to stay afloat. Not exactly a recipe for investing success.
 Sam Subramanian, editor of AlphaProfit Investment Newsletter, Sugar Land, Texas.

United States Natural Gas (UNG): UNG invests in near-month natural gas futures contracts. As each month draws to a close, UNG rolls its position forward by selling the near-month position and buying a contract further from expiration. This helps the fund avoid taking physical delivery of natural gas.

When prices of the longer-dated futures contracts exceed the price of the front-month contract — i.e., an upward sloping forward price curve, also called contango — the fund loses money each time it rolls its position.
UNG currently has two strikes against it. One is the oversupply of natural gas. The other is the price structure of the forward curve.

Weak industrial demand, coupled with excess supplies resulting from investments made in recent years, has caused inventories of natural gas to swell. The U. S. Energy Information Administration states that working gas in storage tallied 2,959 billion cubic feet as of Jan. 7, 2011. As such, gas inventories are 161 bcf above their five-year average of 2,798 bcf.

Looking at the price structure, natural gas for February delivery is currently changing hands at $4.42 per MMBtu. The prices for delivery further out are higher. Prices for deliveries three months, six months and one year out are $4.47, $4.62, and $5.19, respectively. In other words, the natural gas forward price curve is in contango, a situation that is detrimental to the performance of UNG.

If one expects economic recovery to gain further traction in 2011, it is reasonable to assume that industrial demand for natural gas will pick up and enable the price of natural gas to increase in 2011.

A better way to profit from the rise in price of natural gas is through natural gas stocks, either via direct ownership of stocks of natural gas producers or natural gas ETFs such as First Trust ISE-Revere Natural Gas (FCG) or such natural gas mutual funds as Fidelity's Select Natural Gas .

The negative roll yield that will result from natural gas' contango price structure will be a drag on the performance of UNG. UNG should be avoided at least until the natural gas price structure takes on a downward slope, i.e., backwardation, and the positive roll yield will become a tail wind.
 Matt Hougan, president of ETF Analytics, San Francisco.

IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures ETN (VXX) and iPath S&P 500 VIX Mid-Term Futures ETN (VXZ): It is tempting to play volatility here. The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) is trading at its lowest level since before Lehman Bros.' collapse, and products like VXX and VXZ look cheap. Don't be seduced. These products actually track volatility futures, not the VIX itself, and that little difference makes all the difference in the world.

You know how the United States Oil (USO) has trailed spot oil prices for the past year because of contango? The same situation exists in volatility, except it's 10 times worse. VXX lost about 70% of its value in the past year. Given the current shape of the volatility roll curve, it is set to continue its triumphant march towards zero in 2011. Could it spike in the interim? Of course it could, big time. But for long-term investors, VXX is a miss.Most ETFs fulfill the promise of low cost and all-day trade. But some are so rife with flaws, they should be handled with great care or avoided altogether. Emerging market ETFs tumbled into bear market territory as volatility skyrocketed Thursday in the wake of the Fed's so-called "Operation Twist" plan to buy long-term Treasuries. The dollar and bond ETFs continued soaring, with yields falling to record lows, as investors piled into safe havens.
ETFs tracking Hong Kong small caps, Russia, Indonesia, Argentina and Asia excluding Japan fell 6% to as much as 15%. They were all more than 28% off their recent highs.

Yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to a record low of 1.76%. PIMCO 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index (ZROZ) gapped up 5.3%, while iShares Trust Barclays 20+ Year Treasury Bond (TLT) popped 2.8%. C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL) led all nonleveraged exchange traded products, gapping up 17.5% — it's largest one-day move in seven months.

The Fed's program announced Wednesday to buy $400 billion of long-date Treasuries to lower long-term interest rates and revive the economy appears to have backfired. The market's sell-off suggests the Fed has run out of life preservers to throw at the economy.

"We don't see a catalyst to expect a recovery in risk assets," said Warren Smith, a global strategist and partner at the Macro Research Board, based in Montreal. "Undoubtedly, such a catalyst will have to come from Europe, as the Fed has used up all its meaningful bullets.

Adding fuel to the fire, the International Monetary Fund's managing director, Christine Lagarde, said Thursday the global economy has entered a "dangerous phase" and that the heavy debt burdens could "suffocate" a recovery.
Lagarde spoke at a news conference kicking off the annual meetings of the 187-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister lending organization, the World Bank.

Surprisingly, precious metals sold off too as investors dashed to the sidelines. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell 2% in heavy volume and may be finding support at its 10-week moving average. IShares Silver Trust (SLV) gapped down 6% in nearly double usual volume and appears to have found price support at its 40-week moving average, which has served as key support since 2009.

Money managers are selling because gold and silver have hit their stop losses, said David Morgan, a precious metals expert and publisher of the Morgan Report. "And that feeds on itself and that margin means calls. And with margin calls, there's more pressure to the downside."

Based on 30 years of experience, Morgan believes prices will stabilize in about three days and rebound. He believes gold prices could fall to $1,670 an ounce before rebounding to $2,000 an ounce by year's end. It traded at $1,793 an ounce midday Thursday.Emerging market ETFs tumbled into bear market territory as volatility skyrocketed Thursday in the wake of the Fed's so-called "Operation Twist" plan to buy long-term Treasuries. The dollar and bond ETFs continued soaring, with yields falling to record lows, as investors piled into safe havens.ETFs tracking Hong Kong small caps, Russia, Indonesia, Argentina and Asia excluding Japan fell 6% to as much as 15%. They were all more than 28% off their recent highs.Yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to a record low of 1.76%. PIMCO 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index (ZROZ) gapped up 5.3%, while iShares Trust Barclays 20+ Year Treasury Bond (TLT) popped 2.8%. C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL) led all nonleveraged exchange traded products, gapping up 17.5% — it's largest one-day move in seven months.The Fed's program announced Wednesday to buy $400 billion of long-date Treasuries to lower long-term interest rates and revive the economy appears to have backfired. The market's sell-off suggests the Fed has run out of life preservers to throw at the economy."We don't see a catalyst to expect a recovery in risk assets," said Warren Smith, a global strategist and partner at the Macro Research Board, based in Montreal. "Undoubtedly, such a catalyst will have to come from Europe, as the Fed has used up all its meaningful bullets.Adding fuel to the fire, the International Monetary Fund's managing director, Christine Lagarde, said Thursday the global economy has entered a "dangerous phase" and that the heavy debt burdens could "suffocate" a recovery.Lagarde spoke at a news conference kicking off the annual meetings of the 187-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister lending organization, the World Bank.Surprisingly, precious metals sold off too as investors dashed to the sidelines. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell 2% in heavy volume and may be finding support at its 10-week moving average. IShares Silver Trust (SLV) gapped down 6% in nearly double usual volume and appears to have found price support at its 40-week moving average, which has served as key support since 2009.Money managers are selling because gold and silver have hit their stop losses, said David Morgan, a precious metals expert and publisher of the Morgan Report. "And that feeds on itself and that margin means calls. And with margin calls, there's more pressure to the downside."Based on 30 years of experience, Morgan believes prices will stabilize in about three days and rebound. He believes gold prices could fall to $1,670 an ounce before rebounding to $2,000 an ounce by year's end. It traded at $1,793 an ounce midday Thursday.
Dennis Gartman, publisher of the Gartman Letter, has jumped into the exchange traded funds field.
He is teaming up with Mark Fisher, founder of MBF Asset Management, in launching an index and a pair of exchange traded notes based on it.

Gartman and Fisher rolled onto the New Stock Exchange on Wednesday ETRACS Fisher-Gartman Risk On ETN  (ONN) and ETRACS Fisher-Gartman Risk Off ETN (OFF). They track the daily and daily inverse returns of the Fisher-Gartman Risk Index.

The index has a 150% leveraged position in so-called "risk assets" such as global stock ETFs and futures contracts in commodities and certain currencies such as the euro, Australian dollar, Brazilian real and Canadian dollar.

The commodities exposure includes crude oil, heating oil, copper, gasoline, wheat, soybeans and silver. Equity exposure includes ETFs tracking the S&P 500, Europe, Hong Kong, BRIC countries, the Internet and semiconductors.
Meanwhile, 50% of assets are allocated to short positions in "nonrisk asset classes," such as government bonds and "safe haven" currencies such as the yen and Swiss franc.
"The Risk On ETN's value is expected to rise when the outlook on markets and the broader economy is positive and to decrease when such outlook is negative," the ETF providers said in a statement.

The fund can have 150%/50% weighting on the long and short side because short positions appear as a credit to the investor's account. He or she is borrowing shares in hopes of returning them at a later date at a lower price.
The index rebalances quarterly. ONN charges an annual tracking fee of 0.85% of assets and pays an annual distribution of 1%. OFF charges a tracking fee of 1.15%.
Investment Risks
The prospectus notes that the ETNs are geared for sophisticated investors who understand the risk.

The major risks of buying ETNs tracking both long and short positions are 1) both positions could go against you, amplifying losses or 2) both positions move in the same direction, limiting your gains had you been right on one leg of the trade. The ETNs are betting that long and short legs of the trade are inversely correlated and will remain so.
And as with all ETNs, these are debt instruments whose values are tied to the creditworthiness of the issuer, in this case UBS.

"I don't think (ONN/OFF) would have been good vehicles during the 1990s, when 'risk on' was defined by technology, and commodities were being shunned," said Ron Rowland, founder of All Star Investors in Austin, Texas. "Likewise, the 'risk on' trade five or 10 years down the road will likely consist of different market categories or sectors."

ONN and OFF will compete with FactorShares 2X: S&P500 Bull/USD Bear (FSU), FactorShares 2X: S&P500 Bull/TBond Bear (FSE), FactorShares 2X: Oil Bull/S&P500 Bear (FOL), FactorShares 2X: Gold Bull/S&P500 Bear (FSG) and FactorShares 2X: TBond Bull/S&P500 Bear (FSA).
FSG aims to capture gains from a long bet on gold and a short bet on the S&P 500.

Gold is seen as a safe-haven asset that moves independently of the market. But the European debt crisis has at times forced traders to sell gold, causing it to fall, to make up for losses elsewhere in their portfolio.
FSG shot up 35% in August, when gold rose 12% and the S&P fell 5.5%. FSG doubles the difference between a long bet on gold and a short bet on the benchmark.
It gave up much of those gains in September, losing 12%, as both declined, with gold falling 11% and the S&P 500 7.4%.

After months of hearing that "this time it's different," the U.S. is poised to provide the engine of growth to the world economy. That's sweet music to foreign economies, and not a moment too soon. The U.S., despite ongoing problems (huge debt, crippled housing market, depressed consumers), is enjoying an economic rebound. The signs are there: Industrial production, GDP growth…

A weak manufacturing report from China Wednesday underscored the export-driven economy's vulnerabilities to events half a world away. The HSBC bank purchasing managers' index fell to 48 in November from October's 51. Readings above 50 reflect expansion, readings below 50 reflect contraction. November's result was the worst in 32 months. Many analysts blame the European debt crisis, which has yielded…
ETF investors took a beating Wednesday as soaring Italian bond yields deepened fears the country could default on its debts. All stock ETFs sold off as investors sought safety in bonds.

IShares MSCI Italy Index (EWI) — tracking the world's third-largest debtor — led all nonleveraged ETFs lower as it gapped down 9.4%. It booked its largest one-day loss in three years and closed at a one-month low.
IShares MSCI Europe Financials Index (EUFN) plunged 8.1% to a one-month low as investors dumped bank stocks on fears of their exposure to European debt.

PowerShares DB Italian Treasury Bond ETN (ITLY) gapped down 3% to a new low as Italian bond yields vaulted to 7.25% — their highest level since the euro debuted in 1999. They exceeded the 7% mark that forced bailouts in Greece, Portugal and Ireland. Rising yields triggered increases in margin requirements, forcing investors to dump Italian bonds, fueling a vicious cycle.

"Unless the European Central Bank agrees to backstop Italy, which it and Germany have steadfastly refused to do, we don't see any lasting relief on this issue," wrote Alec Young, global equity strategist at S&P Capital IQ. "Italy's surging financing costs are increasing the odds that an Italian bailout will be needed at a time when the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) is widely seen as too small to rescue the slow-growing, debt-laden nation."

IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking foreign developed markets, plummeted 5.1% as it undercut its 10-week moving average for the first time in a month — a very bearish development. IShares MSCI Emerging Markets (EEM) gapped down 5.8%, but is still trading above its 10-week line, showing more strength than developed markets.

Monty Guild, CEO and chief investment officer of Los Angeles-based Guild Investment Management, recommends that investors buy on the dips because the only way for Europe to solve its credit crisis and save its banks is to engage in quantitative easing or printing money. Like when the U.S. engaged in QE in early 2009, the new money supply will boost stocks, real estate and commodities, especially oil and gold, he said.

"It's unimaginable and insane to let the European banks fold because of their exposure to bad loans," Guild said. "What is the alternative, to let the banks fail and every politician in Europe to be disgraced and thrown out of office?"
If Europe doesn't print money, it, the U.S. and Japan will go into a major, decades-long depression with massive foreclosures and unemployment like the 1930s, Guild added.

CurrencyShares Euro Trust (FXE) gapped down 2% to a one-month low as it fell below its 10-week average. On the flip side, PowerShares DB US Dollar Index Bullish (UUP) shot up 1.7% to a one-month high and gapped above its 10-week moving average.
"Safety is everyone's No. 1 priority, and the U.S. dollar and Japanese yen are the most attractive plays," wrote Kathy Lien, director of currency research at GFT.

"It may be too late for Italy to restore confidence, but if European policymakers do not step in with some type of response, we could be looking at months of less credit, balance-sheet deleveraging and uncertainty, which would not bode well for currencies," Lien added.ETF investors took a beating Wednesday as soaring Italian bond yields deepened fears the country could default on its debts. Gold and silver ETFs weakened further alongside global markets Monday as the congressional supercommittee nearly collapsed and the European debt crisis worsened, sending major U.S. indexes back into negative territory for the year.
Meanwhile, economist David Levy projected the U.S. will fall into a recession in 2012 or sooner despite upbeat economic data.

SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell 2.4% as it broke below key price support at its 10-week moving average. Market Vectors Gold Miners ETF (GDX) dropped 1.6% and Market Vectors Junior Gold Miners ETF (GDXJ) 4.9%.
IShares Silver Trust (SLV) skidded 1.9%. It closed in the upper end of its intraday range after falling as much as 5% in the morning.
IPath DJ-UBS Copper ETN (JJC) — a harbinger of industrial production levels — fell 2.9%.

Investors are taking profits from the rally off the October low and have been selling assets to cover margin calls and raise their cash positions, James DiGeorgia, editor of Gold & Energy Advisor, wrote in client note. "Cash is king."

DiGeorgia believes once the sell-off bottoms, gold should be bought because central banks continue to buy gold. In addition, if there's a sovereign debt default, it could lead to a global depression, he says. With massive amounts of debt, the U.S. and Europe will have to print money to pay it off.

Ed Carlson, founder Seattle Technical Advisors, expects gold to fall to $1,480 an ounce. That would translate to $148 a share for GLD or a 10% drop from Monday's close. GLD fell below key price support at its 10-week moving average, marking a bearish development.
SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) fell 2.2% and SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) slid 1.9%.
IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) declined 3.2%; iShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), tracking foreign developed markets, fell 2.6%.
In an about-face to his previous outlook, Monty Guild — founder and CEO of Los Angeles-based Guild Investment Management — recommended selling U.S. and emerging market stocks.

Guild changed his bullish view after reading about a memo leaked to London's Daily Telegraph that stated Germany proposes to create a German-controlled superstate to take over the beleaguered euro zone countries.

"That's going to create a lot of uncertainty, and the markets don't like uncertainty and that's why it sold off today," said Guild. "This will delay (Europe from) doing any quantitative easing and bailout of the banks."

Although many news headlines blamed the sell-off on the supercommittee's failure to come to an agreement over slashing the budget deficit after three months of talks, Guild said he thinks it didn't have anything to do with the sell-off. "No one expects the supercommittee to do anything anyway," he said.
Recession Imminent?
Despite some positive economic conditions such as solid retail sales, corporate spending and exports, the U.S. will likely enter a recession next year or even before, says Levy of the Levy Forecast.

"The main question is whether domestic fiscal policy will lessen or aggravate the recession," Levy wrote. "Domestic profits plateaued in the first half and appear to have held up in the third quarter, but the outlook for the fourth quarter and for 2012 remains a pronounced downward trend."Gold and silver ETFs weakened further alongside global markets Monday as the congressional supercommittee nearly collapsed and the European debt crisis worsened, sending major U.S. indexes back into negative territory for the year.Meanwhile, economist David Levy projected the U.S. will fall into a recession in 2012 or sooner despite upbeat economic data.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell 2.4% as it broke below key price support at its 10-week moving average. ETFs sold off hard across the board Tuesday on news that the Greeks may turn down the second rescue plan hammered out for them by European leaders just last Thursday.
In addition, weaker-than-expected Chinese manufacturing data hit Asian markets.
IShares MSCI Italy Index (EWI), down 6.9%, led all foreign ETFs lower. IShares MSCI France Index (EWQ) sank 5.7% and iShares MSCI Austria Investable Market Index (EWO) fell 5.5%.

"The market is going to continue going up and down based on news out of Europe," said Adrian Day of Adrian Day Asset Management, based in Annapolis, Md. "This whole thing isn't going to end until Greece leaves the euro."

Investors' fears are prompting them to sell on any bad news, Day said. Meanwhile, stocks are trading at cheap valuations, companies are reporting strong profits, U.S. insider buying is at a record and there's a lot of money on the sidelines.

Part of the losses in European ETFs came from the euro's weakness and the dollar's newfound strength. CurrencyShares Euro Trust (FXE), tracking the euro against the greenback, fell 1% as it sank deeper below its 10-week moving average. PowerShares DB U.S. Dollar Index Bullish (UUP), tracking the greenback against a basket of widely traded currencies, rose 1.1% as it recovered its 40-week moving average — a very bullish development.

IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA), the benchmark for developed markets, gapped down 3% and fell for a third straight day. SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), down 2.8%, appears to have hit price resistance at its 200-day moving average after briefly poking above it last week when the Greek rescue plan was mapped out.
IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) gapped down 2.4% Tuesday, but closed in the upper half of its intraday range, which means bargain-hunters came in to support prices.

"From a technical perspective, the equity markets reached a near-term overbought condition," said Alan Zafran, a partner at Menlo Park, Calif.-based Luminous Capital. "The best course of action is to review your investment objectives and dollar cost average."
"Many stocks remain on buy signals from a technical perspective, so holding those positions with a tight stop might make sense depending on one's investment goals," Zafran added.
Winners

The leader among nonleveraged ETFs, C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL), skyrocketed 25% as options traders scrambled to hedge their bets. "Anytime that the VIX pops 15% or more in a single day, it is usually a pretty good marker of a short-term bottom for stock prices," Tom McClellan of the McClellan Market Report wrote.
Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index (ZROZ) shot up 5% on safe-haven buying.

The only equity ETF that bucked the global sell-off, iShares MSCI Hong Kong Index (EWH), rose 1% in nearly five times average trading volume. Hong Kong and Singapore are Adrian Day's favorite emerging markets. They have stronger companies, better accounting standards and more liquidity, Day said.

What's more, they're trading at cheaper valuations than the developed markets and have undervalued currencies, he added. Singapore's market, as tracked by iShares MSCI Singapore Index (EWS), is trading at less than eight times earnings while yielding 4%.ETFs sold off hard across the board Tuesday on news that the Greeks may turn down the second rescue plan hammered out for them by European leaders just last Thursday.In addition, weaker-than-expected Chinese manufacturing data hit Asian markets.IShares MSCI Italy Index (EWI), down 6.9%, led all foreign ETFs lower. They have stronger companies, better accounting standards and more liquidity, Day said.What's more, they're trading at cheaper valuations than the developed markets and have undervalued currencies, he added. Singapore's market, as tracked by iShares MSCI Singapore Index (EWS), is trading at less than eight times earnings while yielding 4%.
The European deal to make lenders take a 50% haircut to Greek government debt and a plan for the region's banks to raise new money ignited a robust, across-the-board global rally Thursday.
The deal aims to forestall, if not prevent, the Greek financial tragedy from spreading. But detractors say the market's rally is just a knee-jerk reaction partly fueled by short covering.
Some of the weakest ETFs this year rallied the most. Guggenheim Solar (TAN) led all nonleveraged ETFs, flying 13.7% to a five-week high.
Volatility ETFs, which tend to move opposite the market, sold off the sharpest, diving 8% to as much as 25% in the case of C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL).

"People were looking for an excuse to buy and this was treated as positive news, so it was off to the races today," said John Carey, a portfolio manager with $11 billion in assets under management at Pioneer Investments. "And there was also fundamental news of higher GDP growth of 2.5% in the third quarter and fairly positive earnings announcements that we've seen on a daily basis."

European financials led overseas markets higher as investors were relieved that banks would recover 50% on their Greek debts vs. nothing. The deal alleviated fears that banks would be nationalized or go bankrupt, Carey said.

IShares MSCI Europe Financials Index (EUFN) gapped up 10%, enjoying its largest one-day gain in its 1 1/2-year trading history. IShares MSCI EAFE Index (EFA) — the benchmark for foreign developed markets — vaulted 5.5% to a two-month high. IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Index (EEM) spiked 6.1%.
Market strategists say although the new plan may prevent Europe's debt crisis from getting worse, austerity plans to deal with the debt may curtail economic growth.

"We've learned over the past two years that we can't trust 'hopium' (hope-based solutions) out of Greece or Europe," said Simon Maierhofer, co-founder of ETFguide.com. "This time is no different. It is prudent to keep long positions on a tight leash and be ready to bail and go short when support is broken."

Part of the gains for U.S. investors in foreign markets came from weakness in the greenback. PowerShares DB U.S. Dollar Index Bullish (UUP), tracking the greenback against a basket of the most widely traded currencies, dove 1.7% to a seven-week low. Investors sold off the safe-haven currency in favor of riskier assets. Owing to the dollar's weakness, SPDR Gold Trust (GLD) jumped 1.3% to a one-month high.

CurrencyShares Euro Trust (FXE) — tracking the euro against the dollar — rallied 2% as investor appetite for risk improved. FXE hit a seven-week high while clearing its 200-day moving average, a key hurdle to confirming an uptrend.

"European banks will need to repatriate funds to meet new capital requirements, which could mean more demand for euros," Kathy Lien, director of currency research at GFT Forex, wrote in her commentary on FX360.com.

In addition, the rescue package provides near-term stability for the financial sector, lifting investors' risk appetite. And traders who were short euros going into the EU summit triggered a wave of short covering, which calls for buying euros to close out their positions, Lien wrote.The European deal to make lenders take a 50% haircut to Greek government debt and a plan for the region's banks to raise new money ignited a robust, across-the-board global rally Thursday.The deal aims to forestall, if not prevent, the Greek financial tragedy from spreading. Copper and copper miners rallied for a second day Tuesday, regaining lost ground from last week's massive sell-off, as the dollar lost value and news emerged that the euro zone's bailout fund may be expanded.

IPath DJ-UBS Copper ETN (JJC) surged 2% to 44.10 after bouncing off of a 52-week low. Global X Copper Miners ETF (COPX) surged as much as 9% intraday and then sold off in the final hour and a half of trading as euro euphoria faded. It closed up 5.7% but in the lower end of its intraday range at 12.82. First Trust ISE Global Copper Index (CU) gapped up 4.3% to 28.57. The red metal rose 5% to $3.44 a pound Tuesday on the Nymex.

"We're seeing value buyers step in to buy the commodity and equities after the weakness that we've seen," said Brian Hicks, co-manager of U.S. Global Investors Global Resources Fund . "It's really a combination of the technically oversold conditions and hopes that we may see a change out of Europe."

JJC, COPX and CU are all trading deep below their long-term 200-day moving averages, which means there's a lot of overhead price resistance. This tends to occur when traders who are losing money on their positions sell into a rally in hopes of breaking even. The red metal and the miners were severely oversold, so its normal to see a sharp rally off the bottom as bargain hunters swoop up shares or traders who were short cover their positions.

"Copper has accelerated into what is probably a short-term selling climax," Waverly Advisors stated in its "Macro Playbook" on Monday. "Be careful of heavy short exposure, as a sharp 'snapback' rally is likely. However, in the longer term, patterns now decisively favor the downside.
"This could potentially change based on the resolution of the current climax, but we believe more downside is likely over the next several months."
In addition, the biggest upside and downside moves occur under the 200-day average. The safest place to buy back these ETFs would be when they cross above their 200-day line.

JJC is trading 28% below its 52-week high and deep into bear market territory. It's lost 26% year to date, lagging the Dow Jones UBS Commodity Index, which has lost 12% year to date. COPX and CU are trading 38% below their 52-week highs and have lost 34% year to date. By contrast the S&P 500 is down 6% for the year.

Copper fell below $2 a pound during the 2008 financial crisis. Hicks, of U.S. Global Investors, doubts it will fall that low again because the sell-off back then was caused by overleveraged hedge funds liquidating positions to raise cash. He believes prices will stabilize at the psychologically significant level of $3 a pound.
"If we go below $3 a pound over the next three to six months, I think China would be interested in buying for their own stockpiles, and that would be supportive for the price of copper," Hicks said.

Tuesday is the first day of trading with new CME margin rules in effect. CME raised the margin required on gold by 21%, silver by 16% and copper by 18%. The metals were expected to sell off more because traders have to put up more money to buy futures contracts on the metals.Copper and copper miners rallied for a second day Tuesday, regaining lost ground from last week's massive sell-off, as the dollar lost value and news emerged that the euro zone's bailout fund may be expanded.IPath DJ-UBS Copper ETN (JJC) surged 2% to 44.10 after bouncing off of a 52-week low. Basic materials and emerging market ETFs led the fledgling global uptrend Wednesday as Fed minutes showed that it's ready to resort to another round of quantitative easing if the economy weakens further and European Union members are set to approve the euro zone rescue fund.

Global X China Industrials ETF (CHII) outpaced all nonleveraged ETFs, gapping up 9.4% to a one-month high. But it's still trading below both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages and its chart hasn't confirmed a new uptrend.
IShares MSCI Indonesia Index (EIDO) and Market Vectors Indonesia Index (IDX) both jumped 5.6% in higher volume than the prior day but still below average.

These corrected considerably less than other foreign markets during the summer sell-off and are trading only 17% below their 52-week highs. Most other countries are still in bear markets or 20% or more below their highs.
IBD Relative Strength Ratings of 58 for EIDO and IDX are also higher than most foreign ETFs, indicating they're outperforming 58% of all issues in the market.
They're poised to lead foreign markets once the uptrend is confirmed, says Kevin Marder of Marder Investment Advisors and the Gilmo Report.
Global X China Materials (CHIM) and EGShares China Infrastructure (CHXX) both gapped up 6% to one-month highs.

IShares MSCI Emerging Markets Materials Index (EMMT), Global X Uranium (URA) and First Trust ISE Global Copper Index (CU) all jumped 5%. But all of these are still trading below their moving averages and so investors must approach them with caution.
The star during the summer sell-off, Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury Index (ZROZ), fell 2.8% to a one-month low.
But it closed in the upper end of its intraday trading range, showing there's demand from bargain buyers.
Volatility ETFs, which move counter to the market, led losing ETFs. C-Tracks Citi Volatility Index ETN (CVOL) crashed 11% and fell below its 50-day moving average for the first time in three months.
Market In New Uptrend

IBD's market timing system shows the market has started an uptrend but investors have to stay nimble and be ready for a possible reversal. This, like many follow-throughs, occurred with the market under its 200-day moving average. Although a new uptrend has been confirmed, many investors still see the 200-day line as overhead resistance, where traders with losses tend to sell as the market rises. The most violent moves up and down tend to occur below the 200-day moving average.

The S&P 500 is up about 12% from its intraday low from last Tuesday and had its biggest seven-day rally since March 2009. The most common month for a bull market to begin is October, said Marder. But volume has been very low.

"You don't have a lot of conviction on the part of institutions," he said. In addition, leading growth stocks haven't built proper bases or ones long enough to take people's attention away from them, he added.

Simon Maierhofer, co-founder of ETFGuide.com, told clients they should wait for stocks to pull back to key support levels before buying into this rally. Investor sentiment hasn't fallen to extreme bearishness that's typically seen at market bottoms, he noted.Basic materials and emerging market ETFs led the fledgling global uptrend Wednesday as Fed minutes showed that it's ready to resort to another round of quantitative easing if the economy weakens further and European Union members are set to approve the euro zone rescue fund.Global X China Industrials ETF (CHII) outpaced all nonleveraged ETFs, gapping up 9.4% to a one-month high. Copper tumbled to a nine-month low this week on speculation that Europe's sovereign-debt problems will erode demand for the industrial metal despite steady demand from China, the largest consumer.

The red metal's melting raises a warning signal for possible lower stock prices. What's more, a reading on the U.S. housing market came in weaker than expected and the International Monetary Fund lowered its global economic growth forecast Tuesday.

Construction of homes and apartments in August fell 5% from July, to 571,000 — its lowest level in three months, the Commerce Department said. The IMF sees 4% worldwide expansion this year and next, cutting back projections for most regions. Three months ago, it estimated growth of 4.3% for this year and 4.5% in 2012.

The so-called metal with a Ph.D. in economics is used to gauge global activity because it's found in all facets of everyday life, from consumer electronics to building infrastructure. Like most commodities, copper has fallen amid the dollar's newfound strength the past month, owing to safe-haven buying spurred by the European debt crisis.

Barclay's iPath Copper ETN  (JJC) has fallen 5.8% so far this week to 48.08 — its lowest price in a year. Since hitting a 52-week high in mid-February, it's been stair-stepping lower, forming a series of lower highs and lower lows.

It has corrected 22% from its 52-week peak and is trading deep below its 200-day moving average. Its shorter-term 50-day moving average has crossed below the 200-day line, which is very bearish. JJC has crumpled 19% year to date but remains ahead 4% in the past 12 months.

"The commodity is becoming oversold, however. This is an area (at around $49) to watch for signs of stabilization," said Kristin Hetzer, a principal at Royal Palms Capital. "This would be a welcome sign for improving economic prospects worldwide."

JJC could drop to the high 30s/low 40s within the next three to six months, says Mark Arbeter, chief technical strategist at S&P Capital IQ. "Copper prices have been a strong leading indicator for stocks," he said. "This is very bearish for the overall stock market."

Likewise copper miners, as tracked by Global X Copper Miners  (COPX) and First Trust ISE Global Copper (CU), skidded to new lows this week. COPX has fallen 28% year to date and 2.4% the past 12 months. CU is down 26% this year but up 2.6% from a year ago.

The S&P 500 has been stair-stepping higher for the past six weeks. It closed at 1207 Tuesday and has corrected only 11% below its 52-week high. It's down 4% year to date but is up 6% in the trailing year.
Lines Of Resistance
It is still in a precarious spot because it also trades below the 200-day average, where trading is most volatile. Its 50-day line has also made a bearish cross below the 200-day line.

"The global economy is still quite weak, particularly here in the U.S.," said Bill Strazzullo, a partner and chief market strategist at Bell Curve Trading. "We believe you will see the S&P 500 trading around 1000 to 950 and the Dow at 9400 to 9000."

Tom McClellan, editor of the McClellan Market Report, wrote in his Sept. 16 newsletter that copper's failure to rally along with the stock market suggests the market will likely give back its gains.Copper tumbled to a nine-month low this week on speculation that Europe's sovereign-debt problems will erode demand for the industrial metal despite steady demand from China, the largest consumer.The red metal's melting raises a warning signal for possible lower stock prices. The New Year has seen a reversal of fortune for some of last year's most battered exchange traded funds. ETFs tracking Indian small caps, Egypt and uranium producers led all others in January. But it's too soon to tell whether they've truly turned north or are just staging a counter-trend rally that will eventually roll south. Those ETFs are trading…
Why do we look overseas for investment opportunities? Because that's where the growth is. But we're also seeing that the hottest markets can fall the hardest when a global correction sets in.
We'll use 16 exchange traded funds, each representing benchmark action on a foreign stock market, and compare those results with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq.
By these gauges, the U.S. has been among the safest places to buy stocks. At least you'd have gotten hurt the least.
Year to date, the Nasdaq has fallen %, the S&P 500 %. Only Canada, rich in resources, has logged a smaller decline: %.
India has been the big loser this year. The Barclays iPath India (INP) exchange traded note has plunged 25.5% in 2011 through Friday's close.
India's problems include high inflation and the inevitable interest-rate hikes to restore price stability.
Much of India's inflation was induced by soaring food costs, which, in turn, were caused by weather-damaged crops.

Like all countries, India stands to lose if a slowdown or recession hits the developed nations. Emerging-market India needs a healthy global economy to maintain its own growth. If the developed world's economies slip, India may tumble.
Investment banker Morgan Stanley revised lower its 2012 Indian economic growth forecast for 2012 to 7.4% from 7.8%.

Morgan Stanley notes India's big stock-market losses and warns those declines will hurt the economy. "Reflexivity is at work — lower share prices are affecting growth and vice versa," Morgan Stanley said.
India's market has taken steep hits the past few weeks. But that market has been falling ever since its Nov. 5 peak.
What's more, India has been lagging the rest of our Daily World Map for quite some time.
The Barclays iPath India ETN has dropped 14% in the past 12 months, tying it for the worst record with the Guggenheim China Small Cap (HAO) ETF.
Guggenheim China Small Cap, in fact, holds the second worst year-to-date result among these 18 markets. Its 22.9% decline is far worse than the 15.9% drop posted by iShares FTSE China 25 (FXI).
Why the big difference? The small-cap ETF is more volatile, as you'd expect. The big-cap FXI reflects the action of 25 of China's biggest publicly held companies.
The FXI's top 10 holdings include two telecoms, three energy companies and five financial institutions.

While most have lost ground, especially the banks, one doesn't see the sort of swings as appear in the small-cap holdings. Those names include China Shanshui Cement, BBMG (another concrete producer), Mindray Medical (MR), Tsingtao Brewery and Great Wall Motor.

Some have fallen hard, some are holding up. But almost any name on that list is more volatile than those on the FXI. That puts the small-cap ETF in a vulnerable spot during any market downturn.Why do we look overseas for investment opportunities? Because that's where the growth is. But almost any name on that list is more volatile than those on the FXI. That puts the small-cap ETF in a vulnerable spot during any market downturn.

More weakness in India and Indonesia led a global sell-off Monday on worries that they will raise interest rates to control inflation.

India's central bank is expected to raise rates sooner than anticipated to stave off food inflation. An Indonesian central bank authority said Monday that it's ready to hike rates if food and oil prices keep rising.
"[This] is a microcosm of the headwinds facing emerging markets looking forward," Alan Zafran, partner at Menlo Park, Calif.-based Luminous Capital, wrote in an e-mail.

"The underlying economic growth outlook for these countries remains solid," he added. "But should inflation get out of control, these countries' central banks will be forced to impose restrictive monetary policies that will hamper the economic growth being forecast."

India's GDP grew 9.7% in 2010 and is seen growing 8.4% in 2011, according to the International Monetary Fund. Indonesia's economy is estimated to have grown 5.9% in 2010 and is projected to expand 6.1% in 2011, according to Moody's Economy.com.
WisdomTree India Earnings (EPI) gapped down 2.4% and iPath MSCI India Index ETN (INP) gapped down 3% to six-week lows.
Asia's 2010 performance leader, Market Vectors Indonesia Index (IDX), gapped down 5% in more than 1 1/2 times average volume, booking its largest one-day drop in seven months.
Technical Weakness

Emerging markets overall, which outpaced the U.S. since the March 2009 bottom, have been underperforming the U.S. since November. They've failed to join U.S. indexes in making new highs in the new year.

"That's usually a signal that something unpleasant is likely to happen to global equity markets because these markets should be the ones leading the way up and they aren't," said Vinny Catalano, president of Blue Marble Research.
Although the bull market hasn't signaled that it's over, emerging markets are likely to correct more and investors should wait until the correction ends, Catalano says.

EPI closed just above its 200-day average. And INP closed right on that key line. They've corrected 14% from their 52-week highs, so they're not in a confirmed bear market, which by definition is a 20% drop from a 52-week high.
The biggest downside moves often happen below the 200-day line. When INP closed below its 200-day in February of 2008, it fell 68%. It took 15 months for it to recover that line.
EPI and INP both returned 20% in 2010, outdoing the benchmark MSCI Emerging Markets index's 15% gain.

On a valuation basis, India's market is expensive relative to the rest of Asia. It's trading at nearly 19 times 2010 earnings and 15.3 times 2011 earnings, according to Credit Suisse. By contrast Asia Pacific is trading at 15 times 2010 earnings and 13.3 times 2011 earnings.

India is expected to grow earnings by 24% in 2010 and 22% in 2011, while Asia overall grows earnings by 47% and 14% during those periods. Credit Suisse analysts recommend underweighting the country because there was too much foreign buying in 2010.

"(India's) valuations are very high," Carl Delfeld, founder of iGlobalStrategist.com, wrote in an e-mail. "And despite (its) raising interest rates six times in 2010, its central bank is behind the inflation curve and they will have to keep raising rates."

IDX has corrected 13% from its 52-week high. It closed Monday just above its 200-day moving average, its lowest price in five months. It's formed a bearish head-and-shoulders or rounded-top chart pattern, a shape that many investors use as a sell signal.

IDX outpaced all major Asian markets in 2010, returning 40%. Indonesia's market is also trading at a slight premium compared to the region. It's trading at 16.4 times 2010 earnings and 13.5 times 2011 earnings, according to Credit Suisse. It's projected to grow earnings by 20% in 2010 and 21% in 2011.More weakness in India and Indonesia led a global sell-off Monday on worries that they will raise interest rates to control inflation.India's central bank is expected to raise rates sooner than anticipated to stave off food inflation. An Indonesian central bank authority said Monday that it's ready to hike rates if food and oil prices keep rising."[This] is a microcosm of the headwinds facing emerging markets looking forward," Alan Zafran, partner at Menlo Park, Calif.-based Luminous Capital, wrote in an e-mail."The underlying economic growth outlook for these countries remains solid," he added. ETF investors turned defensive in May as Greece's debt problems swelled and negative economic news flooded the headlines. They dumped stocks and piled into bonds and money market funds. In a rude awakening for brew-it-yourself caffeine addicts, Starbucks (SBUX) jacked up packaged-coffee prices by a scorching 17% on Wednesday.

J.M. Smucker (SJM) also caused a stir the day before by raising wholesale coffee prices by 11%, owing to tight raw-bean supplies. Sara Lee (SLE), Kraft Foods (KFT) and Peet's Coffee & Tea (PEET) also raised prices in the past year.
Earlier this month, arabica coffee hit a 34-year peak of $3.0890 a pound. It has since corrected about 14%, though it trades nearly double from year-ago levels.

The drop this month came as commodity prices fell across the board, along with stocks. Good weather conditions also gave way to a record off-year harvest in Brazil — the world's largest arabica bean grower.

Shawn Hackett, a commodities trading expert, says the coffee bull run has turned cold, barring a frost or drought that hurts fall and summer production. The president of Hackett Financial Services foresaw coffee prices' rise last year.

"Off-season crop yields (bags per hectare) have risen 45% over the last four crop cycles, which is an astounding achievement for Brazil," Hackett wrote in his commodities newsletter released Wednesday. "Demand will not grow fast enough to overcome such a prolific surge in off-season crop."

IPath DJ-UBS Coffee Tracking Sub-Index ETN (JO) rose 2% to 69.99 on Wednesday. It's up 9.4% year to date and 89% in the past 12 months, significantly outpacing agricultural commodities. They're flat for 2011 and up 53% from a year ago.
JO has corrected 14% from its all-time high and is consolidating below its 10-week moving average.
Reheating Before Cooling
Goldman Sachs commodities analysts say prices will heat up in the next three to six months before cooling off in 12 months.

"Excessive rains in Colombia are putting local arabica production at risk," Goldman analysts wrote in a research report released Tuesday. "The outlook for lower global 2011-12 production (resulting from) Brazil's off-year of the arabica plant two-year cycle in the face of both strong emerging-market demand growth and very low beginning stocks will likely support prices in 2011."

Barring abnormal weather conditions, they expect prices to ease in 12 months as farmers increase production in response to higher prices. Prices could fall even more should Brazil enjoy a robust "on-year" harvest in 2012.

Production of high-quality arabica beans has been low in several key growing countries around the world. Colombia has turned in three straight below-par crops. Central American production has been in a long-term decline in reaction to low prices in 2000 and 2004.
Farmers in Vietnam — the largest robusta coffee grower — have sold 90% of their crop to take advantage of higher prices. Supplies may be tight until the next harvest begins in October.

Higher prices haven't deterred buyers from getting their morning fix. Global coffee consumption rose 2.4% to a record 134 million 60-kilogram bags in 2010, according to the International Coffee Organization.

Demand has grown 2.5% a year for the past 10 years thanks to China and other Asian countries. Starbucks intends to triple its stores in mainland China, from 450 now to 1,500 by 2015.In a rude awakening for brew-it-yourself caffeine addicts, Starbucks (SBUX) jacked up packaged-coffee prices by a scorching 17% on Wednesday.J.M. Crude oil and energy ETFs defied a global market swoon Wednesday as WTI crude oil popped to nearly $102 a barrel, a five-month high.

This came as Canadian energy giant Enbridge said it would reverse the Seaway pipeline's flow direction, which was causing a lot of oversupply in the central U.S. What's more, a decline in U.S. crude oil supplies last week reported by Department of Energy was steeper than analysts expected. Oil presents a solid investment opportunity for ETF investors, say market strategists and energy experts.
United States Oil (USO), PowerShares DB Oil (DBO) and iPath Pure Beta Crude Oil ETN (OLEM) surged 2.4% to 3.9%, outperforming most other nonleveraged ETFs.

USO, the most widely traded ETF tracking crude oil futures, cleared prior price resistance at 39.25 to close at 39.33. Its next level of price resistance lies at 40.74. It's IBD Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved from E (the lowest possible) to B-, indicating it's under heavy institutional accumulation.

"Prices gapped up through a significant resistance level at $39 and that was accompanied by a significant increase of volume," said Zev Spiro, CEO and chief market technician at Orips Research. "This gap needs to be monitored over the next few days to determine whether the break above resistance confirms, or if it is an exhaustion gap that would signal a halt to the current uptrend and possibly a full reversal."

Brent crude oil futures ticked up 0.4% to $112.39 a barrel, shrinking the price gap between oil traded overseas and WTI, or West Texas Intermediate, traded in the U.S. The Seaway pipeline is the only pipeline that connects the Gulf Coast refining hub to Cushing, Okla. It was creating a glut of WTI crude in the landlocked central U.S., keeping prices low.

"The Seaway pipeline currently flows from the Gulf to Cushing, benefiting Midwestern refineries. But when the pipeline's flow is reversed, more land-locked crude will flow to the Gulf," wrote Chris Lafakis, an economist at Moodys.com. "And since landlocked crude is the reason why WTI trades at a discount to Brent, the reversal of Seaway will materially dent the WTI/Brent spread.

"Already, the spread has fallen to just under $10, its lowest level since early May. While the spread will persist until another pipeline is built from Cushing to the Gulf to transport the large amount of new crude being pumped in North Dakota and Canada, the reversal of Seaway has greatly diminished the WTI/Brent price discrepancy in the meantime."
U.S. Supply And Demand
U.S. crude oil stockpiles declined by 1.1 million barrels to 337 million barrels, according to data released Wednesday by the Department of Energy. Analysts had expected an 800,000 barrel decline.
Oil prices are bound to keep on rising in the long run owing to rampant demand in emerging markets, said Dave Fessler, an energy and infrastructure analyst at InvestmentU.com.

People in China, India, Brazil and other South American countries are buying autos at record rates and that demand has more than made up for the lower demand in the U.S. Production has only kept pace with demand, and over the past 10 years the experts have underestimated future production growth and had to lower their forecasts as a result, he said.
"China is going to use 9 million barrels a day more by 2030. India is going to use 5 billion barrels a day more," Fessler said.

Based on his technical and quantitative analysis, Waverly Advisors' Chief Investment Officer Adam Grimes projects front-month oil futures will soon reach $108 to $110 a barrel. He recommends waiting for a pullback in prices to buy on weakness because oil has been rising for almost seven weeks straight and will likely need to take a breather before continuing higher.

A higher price for crude is bearish for oil refiners and markets like Valero (VLO) but very bullish for producers, explorers, and oil and gas equipment and services providers found in ETFs like Oil Services Holdrs (OIH), which rose 0.09% Wednesday; SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production (XOP), down 1.3%, and SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Equipment & Services (XES), up 0.6%.
These all rallied intraday Wednesday and reversed lower in the last two hours of trading.

Kristin Hetzer, a market technician and a principal at Royal Palms Capital, forecasts crude will rise to $114 a barrel, up 12% from Wednesday's close. Her price target for the OIH is $177, up 37% from Wednesday's price.

"From the looks of the (oil) stocks and the ETFs, one could reason that demand continues for energy products and the business appears to be improving as well as the outlook," Hetzer said.Crude oil and energy ETFs defied a global market swoon Wednesday as WTI crude oil popped to nearly $102 a barrel, a five-month high.This came as Canadian energy giant Enbridge said it would reverse the Seaway pipeline's flow direction, which was causing a lot of oversupply in the central U.S. What's more, a decline in U.S. crude oil supplies last week reported by Department of Energy was steeper than analysts expected. Some of tech's biggest companies are plugging into the smart-building field.

This market, also called building IT, isn't about installing solar panels or thermal windows. Rather, the goal is to make buildings smarter by applying information technology hardware, software and services to analyze and improve systems that provide a building's utilities, says Michael LoCascio, an analyst with Lux Research.
Building IT is a subset of the fast-emerging cleantech and smart energy grid fields.
"There's a lot of innovation going on," in building IT, LoCascio said. "These technologies provide valuable new information to energy users."
Buildings with intelligent sensors, which analyze and control heat, light and more, can cut energy consumption by 20% on average, and lighting use by up to 60%, says a new Lux study.

By sensing employee access badges, building IT software can even monitor worker traffic patterns and adjust building energy levels as needed, says Florence Hudson, IBM (IBM) vice president of energy and environment.
"In effect, this gives brains and eyes to the building," Hudson said.

Unlike pricey construction retrofits, building IT requires a relatively small upfront cost and can yield savings quickly. IBM, Cisco Systems (CSCO), Microsoft (MSFT) and even Infosys (INFY) and Google (GOOG) have jumped in with new software and services to reduce energy waste.
"For IT companies, this is a real turn of events," LoCascio said. "Suddenly, this market isn't just for the building and lighting control companies anymore."

The field is attracting dozens of startups. One is Green Plug of San Ramon, Calif. It makes smart digital power adapters — plugs that can monitor how much power is being used at different places in a building.

Traditional building management systems, or BMS, software — from companies such as Johnson Controls (JCI), Siemens (SI), Honeywell International (HON), Eaton (ETN) and Schneider Electric — rely on networked sensors or chips to gather relevant data. Building managers have long used such systems to track heating, cooling, ventilation, lighting, power and water usage across their facilities.

Now, tech vendors are adding analytics programs and computer dashboards to better parse the data. Such systems can spot wasteful consumption of electricity, lighting, heat, water and more. The systems can send out problem alerts to maintenance workers or adjust building settings on the fly.
Buildings consume 38% of the primary energy used across 33 developed countries studied by Lux. Nearly three-fourths of that amount stems from the electricity to power commercial structures and homes.

Current power consumption creates 6 billion metric tons of global carbon emissions per year, Lux says. The cost of electricity and natural gas consumed by buildings in the developed world comes to about $1.26 trillion a year, it says.
Yet, just 7% of commercial buildings in both the U.S. and the developed world have installed any smart controls at all, says LoCascio.
"The number is shockingly low," he said.

Combining new IT systems with efficient building controls could save $1 trillion in global energy costs by 2020, according to McKinsey & Co. The consulting firm says a U.S. investment in smart-building technologies of $50 billion per year here over a decade would create 900,000 jobs and cut greenhouse gas emissions by 1.1 billion tons.
IBM expects annual sales of building IT technology will exceed $6 billion by 2015.

IBM has teamed with Johnson Controls to build new in-house data analysis software for its 1,700 buildings worldwide, and it teams with Johnson Controls and most of the other big controls makers to see that their products work with IBM's commercial software line, called Maximo. The next version of Maximo is set for release next month.

The smart-building software and more that IBM uses at its own main campus in Armonk, N.Y., has saved the company some $370 million over the past 20 years in improved efficiency, the company says. IBM's Hudson says the software detected that an air compressor was unnecessarily turned on during the Thanksgiving break, and it then automatically turned the compressor off, saving IBM some utility costs.

"We're helping our clients manage their facilities in the same way that we already manage data centers and IT," Hudson said. "They need to manage this issue more holistically across all their facilities."

Lots of tech vendors have gotten active in the building IT market. Microsoft's Hohm and Google's PowerMeter are smart metering systems to track home energy use. Both partner with utilities to offer software that homeowners can download. Cisco's product line for businesses is called EnergyWise. Cisco's efforts to build its smart grid business includes acquiring companies in this field, including Richards-Zeta Building Intelligence and Arch Rock.

Tech services firm Infosys partnered with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in November to develop EnergyPlus, software that simulates how buildings are using energy. The software helps designers, builders and property owners model building energy savings.

In September, Cisco partnered with Duke Energy (DUK) to make commercial buildings more efficient in downtown Charlotte, N.C. The $5.3 million pilot project combines smart grids and building automation controls with energy tracking software, sensors and more. Building owners, tenants and managers can get real-time updates about energy consumption rates.Some of tech's biggest companies are plugging into the smart-building field.This market, also called building IT, isn't about installing solar panels or thermal windows. IBM's Hudson says the software detected that an air compressor was unnecessarily turned on during the Thanksgiving break, and it then automatically turned the compressor off, saving IBM some utility costs."We're helping our clients manage their facilities in the same way that we already manage data centers and IT," Hudson said. "They need to manage this issue more holistically across all their facilities."Lots of tech vendors have gotten active in the building IT market. Microsoft's Hohm and Google's PowerMeter are smart metering systems to track home energy use. Both partner with utilities to offer software that homeowners can download. Cisco's product line for businesses is called EnergyWise. Cisco's efforts to build its smart grid business includes acquiring companies in this field, including Richards-Zeta Building Intelligence and Arch Rock.Tech services firm Infosys partnered with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in November to develop EnergyPlus, software that simulates how buildings are using energy. The software helps designers, builders and property owners model building energy savings.In September, Cisco partnered with Duke Energy (DUK) to make commercial buildings more efficient in downtown Charlotte, N.C. The $5.3 million pilot project combines smart grids and building automation controls with energy tracking software, sensors and more. Building owners, tenants and managers can get real-time updates about energy consumption rates.

Emerson Electric Co. (EMR  -  Free Report) yesterday announced that it has successfully completed $810-million buyout of Tools and Test Equipment business of Textron Inc. (TXT  -  Free Report). The buyout, originally announced on Apr 18, will fortify Emerson’s position in the global professional tools market.Rockford, IL-based Tools & Test primarily engages in manufacturing instruments related to test and measurement and diagnostics. It also produces utility and electrical tools. Prime tool brands offered by Tools & Test include Klauke and Greenlee. Tools & Test operates 11 manufacturing facilities globally and has a workforce of 2,300 people. It generated roughly $470 million in revenues in 2017. Details of BuyoutAs noted, the acquired assets of Tools & Test will be integrated with Ridge Tool business of Emerson. Ridge Tool is part of the company’s Tools & Home Products business — one of the two businesses comprising the company’s Commercial & Residential Solutions segment.The combined business of Tools & Test, and Ridge Tool — anticipated to be worth more than $1 billion — will strengthen Emerson’s existing product offerings to electrical, plumbing and mechanical contractors. Moreover, it will fortify the company’s presence in European markets.Furthermore, Emerson anticipates this buyout to boost cash flow immediately while predicts earnings accretion in fiscal 2019 (ending September 2019). Snapshot of Emerson’s Inorganic InitiativesWe believe that the above-mentioned transaction is consistent with Emerson’s policy of acquiring meaningful businesses to gain access to new customers, regions and product lines.Prior to this buyout, in May 2018, Emerson signed an agreement to acquire Aventics — a Germany-based leader in pneumatics technologies. The buyout will cost the company €527 million and will be completed in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2018 (ending September 2018). In January 2018, the company completed the buyout of ProSys Inc., thereby adding new technologies to its Operational Certainty initiative while the buyout of Cooper-Atkins has been strengthening its portfolio of cold chain technology.It’s worth mentioning here that acquisitions/divestitures have a positive impact of 8% on sales growth in the second quarter of fiscal 2018 (ended March 2018). Zacks Rank & Other Key PicksWith a market capitalization of nearly $43.8 billion, Emerson currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). We believe that the company’s inorganic initiatives will add more vigor to its product offerings and help in keeping market sentiments positive for the stock.Emerson’s share price gained 0.4% yesterday, closing the trading session at $69.44, while it has rallied roughly 2% in the past three months. The three-month gain comfortably surpassed 1.6% decline of the industry.Also, the company’s earnings estimates have been revised upward in the past 60 days. Currently, the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $3.18 for fiscal 2018 reflects growth of 0.3% over the 60-day ago tally.Emerson Electric Co. Price and Consensus  Emerson Electric Co.
